paragraph.label: 1026-36-j-2
paragraph.content: For purposes of this paragraph (j), “depository institution” has the meaning in section 1503(2) of the SAFE Act, 12 U.S.C. 5102(2). For purposes of this paragraph (j), “subsidiary” has the meaning in section 3 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act, 12 U.S.C. 1813.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-vii
paragraph.content: The circumstances under which any prepayment penalty, as defined in § 1026.32(b)(6)(i), may be imposed, such as when paying the loan in full or selling or refinancing the principal dwelling; the time period during which such a penalty may be imposed; and a statement that the consumer may contact the servicer for additional information, including the maximum amount of the penalty.

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-6-ii
paragraph.content: [Reserved]

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d
paragraph.title: Content and layout of the periodic statement.
paragraph.content: Content and layout of the periodic statement. The periodic statement required by this section shall include:

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-1
paragraph.title: Amount due.
paragraph.content: Amount due. Grouped together in close proximity to each other and located at the top of the first page of the statement:

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-1-i
paragraph.content: The payment due date;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-1-ii
paragraph.content: The amount of any late payment fee, and the date on which that fee will be imposed if payment has not been received; and

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-1-iii
paragraph.content: The amount due, shown more prominently than other disclosures on the page and, if the transaction has multiple payment options, the amount due under each of the payment options.

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-2
paragraph.title: Explanation of amount due.
paragraph.content: Explanation of amount due. The following items, grouped together in close proximity to each other and located on the first page of the statement:

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-2-i
paragraph.content: The monthly payment amount, including a breakdown showing how much, if any, will be applied to principal, interest, and escrow and, if a mortgage loan has multiple payment options, a breakdown of each of the payment options along with information on whether the principal balance will increase, decrease, or stay the same for each option listed;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-2-ii
paragraph.content: The total sum of any fees or charges imposed since the last statement; and

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-2-iii
paragraph.content: Any payment amount past due.

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-3
paragraph.title: Past Payment Breakdown.
paragraph.content: Past Payment Breakdown. The following items, grouped together in close proximity to each other and located on the first page of the statement:

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-3-i
paragraph.content: The total of all payments received since the last statement, including a breakdown showing the amount, if any, that was applied to principal, interest, escrow, fees and charges, and the amount, if any, sent to any suspense or unapplied funds account; and

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-3-ii
paragraph.content: The total of all payments received since the beginning of the current calendar year, including a breakdown of that total showing the amount, if any, that was applied to principal, interest, escrow, fees and charges, and the amount, if any, currently held in any suspense or unapplied funds account.

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-4
paragraph.title: Transaction activity.
paragraph.content: Transaction activity. A list of all the transaction activity that occurred since the last statement. For purposes of this paragraph (d)(4), transaction activity means any activity that causes a credit or debit to the amount currently due. This list must include the date of the transaction, a brief description of the transaction, and the amount of the transaction for each activity on the list.

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-5
paragraph.title: Partial payment information.
paragraph.content: Partial payment information. If a statement reflects a partial payment that was placed in a suspense or unapplied funds account, information explaining what must be done for the funds to be applied. The information must be on the front page of the statement or, alternatively, may be included on a separate page enclosed with the periodic statement or in a separate letter.

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-6
paragraph.title: Contact information.
paragraph.content: Contact information. A toll-free telephone number and, if applicable, an electronic mailing address that may be used by the consumer to obtain information about the consumer's account, located on the front page of the statement.

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-7
paragraph.title: Account information.
paragraph.content: Account information. The following information:

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-7-i
paragraph.content: The amount of the outstanding principal balance;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-7-ii
paragraph.content: The current interest rate in effect for the mortgage loan;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-7-iii
paragraph.content: The date after which the interest rate may next change;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-7-iv
paragraph.content: The existence of any prepayment penalty, as defined in § 1026.32(b)(6)(i), that may be charged;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-7-v
paragraph.content: The Web site to access either the Bureau list or the HUD list of homeownership counselors and counseling organizations and the HUD toll-free telephone number to access contact information for homeownership counselors or counseling organizations; and

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-8
paragraph.title: Delinquency information.
paragraph.content: Delinquency information. If the consumer is more than 45 days delinquent, the following items, grouped together in close proximity to each other and located on the first page of the statement or, alternatively, on a separate page enclosed with the periodic statement or in a separate letter:

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-8-i
paragraph.content: The date on which the consumer became delinquent;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-8-ii
paragraph.content: A notification of possible risks, such as foreclosure, and expenses, that may be incurred if the delinquency is not cured;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-8-iii
paragraph.content: An account history showing, for the previous six months or the period since the last time the account was current, whichever is shorter, the amount remaining past due from each billing cycle or, if any such payment was fully paid, the date on which it was credited as fully paid;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-8-iv
paragraph.content: A notice indicating any loss mitigation program to which the consumer has agreed, if applicable;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-8-v
paragraph.content: A notice of whether the servicer has made the first notice or filing required by applicable law for any judicial or non-judicial foreclosure process, if applicable;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-8-vi
paragraph.content: The total payment amount needed to bring the account current; and

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-8-vii
paragraph.content: A reference to the homeownership counselor information disclosed pursuant to paragraph (d)(7)(v) of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-41-c
paragraph.title: Form of the periodic statement.
paragraph.content: Form of the periodic statement. The servicer must make the disclosures required by this section clearly and conspicuously in writing, or electronically if the consumer agrees, and in a form that the consumer may keep. Sample forms for periodic statements are provided in appendix H-30. Proper use of these forms complies with the requirements of this paragraph (c) and the layout requirements in paragraph (d) of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-41-b
paragraph.title: Timing of the periodic statement.
paragraph.content: Timing of the periodic statement. The periodic statement must be delivered or placed in the mail within a reasonably prompt time after the payment due date or the end of any courtesy period provided for the previous billing cycle.

paragraph.label: 1026-41-a
paragraph.title: In general.
paragraph.content: In general.

paragraph.label: 1026-41-a-1
paragraph.title: Scope.
paragraph.content: Scope. This section applies to a closed-end consumer credit transaction secured by a dwelling, unless an exemption in paragraph (e) of this section applies. Such transactions are referred to as mortgage loans for the purposes of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-41-a-2
paragraph.title: Periodic statements.
paragraph.content: Periodic statements. A servicer of a transaction subject to this section shall provide the consumer, for each billing cycle, a periodic statement meeting the requirements of paragraphs (b), (c), and (d) of this section. If a mortgage loan has a billing cycle shorter than a period of 31 days (for example, a bi-weekly billing cycle), a periodic statement covering an entire month may be used. For the purposes of this section, servicer includes the creditor, assignee, or servicer, as applicable. A creditor or assignee that does not currently own the mortgage loan or the mortgage servicing rights is not subject to the requirement in this section to provide a periodic statement.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-A-2
paragraph.content: The maximum payment in the payment schedule, including any balloon payment, for a higher-priced covered transaction;

paragraph.label: 1026-32-a-2-ii
paragraph.content: A reverse mortgage transaction subject to § 1026.33.

paragraph.label: 1026-1-d-5
paragraph.content: Subpart E contains special rules for mortgage transactions. Section 1026.32 requires certain disclosures and provides limitations for closed-end loans that have rates or fees above specified amounts. Section 1026.33 requires special disclosures, including the total annual loan cost rate, for reverse mortgage transactions. Section 1026.34 prohibits specific acts and practices in connection with closed-end mortgage transactions that are subject to § 1026.32. Section 1026.35 prohibits specific acts and practices in connection with closed-end higher-priced mortgage loans, as defined in § 1026.35(a). Section 1026.36 prohibits specific acts and practices in connection with an extension of credit secured by a dwelling.

paragraph.label: 1026-18-f
paragraph.title: Variable rate.
paragraph.content: Variable rate.

paragraph.label: 1026-18-f-1
paragraph.content: Except as provided in paragraph (f)(3) of this section, if the annual percentage rate may increase after consummation in a transaction not secured by the consumer's principal dwelling or in a transaction secured by the consumer's principal dwelling with a term of one year or less, the following disclosures:

paragraph.label: 1026-18-f-1-i
paragraph.content: The circumstances under which the rate may increase.

paragraph.label: 1026-18-f-1-ii
paragraph.content: Any limitations on the increase.

paragraph.label: 1026-18-f-1-iii
paragraph.content: The effect of an increase.

paragraph.label: 1026-18-f-1-iv
paragraph.content: An example of the payment terms that would result from an increase.

paragraph.label: 1026-18-f-2
paragraph.content: If the annual percentage rate may increase after consummation in a transaction secured by the consumer's principal dwelling with a term greater than one year, the following disclosures:

paragraph.label: 1026-18-f-2-i
paragraph.content: The fact that the transaction contains a variable-rate feature.

paragraph.label: 1026-18-f-2-ii
paragraph.content: A statement that variable-rate disclosures have been provided earlier.

paragraph.label: 1026-18-f-3
paragraph.content: Information provided in accordance with §§ 1026.18(f)(2) and 1026.19(b) may be substituted for the disclosures required by paragraph (f)(1) of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-A-1
paragraph.content: The maximum payment scheduled during the first five years after the date on which the first regular periodic payment will be due for a loan that is not a higher-priced covered transaction; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-2-v
paragraph.content: The consumer has made no payments more than 30 days late during the six months immediately preceding the creditor's receipt of the consumer's written application for the standard mortgage; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-7
paragraph.title: Monthly debt-to-income ratio or residual income
paragraph.content: Monthly debt-to-income ratio or residual income —

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-7-i
paragraph.title: Definitions.
paragraph.content: Definitions. For purposes of this paragraph (c)(7), the following definitions apply:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-7-i-A
paragraph.title: Total monthly debt obligations.
paragraph.content: Total monthly debt obligations. The term total monthly debt obligations means the sum of: the payment on the covered transaction, as required to be calculated by paragraphs (c)(2)(iii) and (c)(5) of this section; simultaneous loans, as required by paragraphs (c)(2)(iv) and (c)(6) of this section; mortgage-related obligations, as required by paragraph (c)(2)(v) of this section; and current debt obligations, alimony, and child support, as required by paragraph (c)(2)(vi) of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-7-i-B
paragraph.title: Total monthly income.
paragraph.content: Total monthly income. The term total monthly income means the sum of the consumer's current or reasonably expected income, including any income from assets, as required by paragraphs (c)(2)(i) and (c)(4) of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-7-ii
paragraph.title: Calculations—
paragraph.content: Calculations—

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-7-ii-A
paragraph.title: Monthly debt-to-income ratio.
paragraph.content: Monthly debt-to-income ratio. If a creditor considers the consumer's monthly debt-to-income ratio under paragraph (c)(2)(vii) of this section, the creditor must consider the ratio of the consumer's total monthly debt obligations to the consumer's total monthly income.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-7-ii-B
paragraph.title: Monthly residual income.
paragraph.content: Monthly residual income. If a creditor considers the consumer's monthly residual income under paragraph (c)(2)(vii) of this section, the creditor must consider the consumer's remaining income after subtracting the consumer's total monthly debt obligations from the consumer's total monthly income.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-i
paragraph.content: A statement providing:

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-i-A
paragraph.content: An explanation that under the terms of the consumer's adjustable-rate mortgage, the specific time period in which the current interest rate has been in effect is ending and the interest rate and mortgage payment will change;

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-i-B
paragraph.content: The effective date of the interest rate adjustment and when additional future interest rate adjustments are scheduled to occur; and

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-i-C
paragraph.content: Any other changes to loan terms, features, or options taking effect on the same date as the interest rate adjustment, such as the expiration of interest-only or payment-option features.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5
paragraph.title: Payment calculation
paragraph.content: Payment calculation —

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-i
paragraph.title: General rule.
paragraph.content: General rule. Except as provided in paragraph (c)(5)(ii) of this section, a creditor must make the consideration required under paragraph (c)(2)(iii) of this section using:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-i-A
paragraph.content: The fully indexed rate or any introductory interest rate, whichever is greater; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-i-B
paragraph.content: Monthly, fully amortizing payments that are substantially equal.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii
paragraph.title: Special rules for loans with a balloon payment, interest-only loans, and negative amortization loans.
paragraph.content: Special rules for loans with a balloon payment, interest-only loans, and negative amortization loans. A creditor must make the consideration required under paragraph (c)(2)(iii) of this section for:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-A
paragraph.content: A loan with a balloon payment, as defined in § 1026.18(s)(5)(i), using:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-A-1
paragraph.content: The maximum payment scheduled during the first five years after the date on which the first regular periodic payment will be due for a loan that is not a higher-priced covered transaction; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-A-2
paragraph.content: The maximum payment in the payment schedule, including any balloon payment, for a higher-priced covered transaction;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-B
paragraph.content: An interest-only loan, as defined in § 1026.18(s)(7)(iv), using:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-B-1
paragraph.content: The fully indexed rate or any introductory interest rate, whichever is greater; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-B-2
paragraph.content: Substantially equal, monthly payments of principal and interest that will repay the loan amount over the term of the loan remaining as of the date the loan is recast.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-C
paragraph.content: A negative amortization loan, as defined in § 1026.18(s)(7)(v), using:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-C-1
paragraph.content: The fully indexed rate or any introductory interest rate, whichever is greater; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-C-2
paragraph.content: Substantially equal, monthly payments of principal and interest that will repay the maximum loan amount over the term of the loan remaining as of the date the loan is recast.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-4
paragraph.title: Verification of income or assets.
paragraph.content: Verification of income or assets. A creditor must verify the amounts of income or assets that the creditor relies on under § 1026.43(c)(2)(i) to determine a consumer's ability to repay a covered transaction using third-party records that provide reasonably reliable evidence of the consumer's income or assets. A creditor may verify the consumer's income using a tax-return transcript issued by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). Examples of other records the creditor may use to verify the consumer's income or assets include:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-4-i
paragraph.content: Copies of tax returns the consumer filed with the IRS or a State taxing authority;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-4-ii
paragraph.content: IRS Form W-2s or similar IRS forms used for reporting wages or tax withholding;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-4-iii
paragraph.content: Payroll statements, including military Leave and Earnings Statements;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-4-iv
paragraph.content: Financial institution records;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-4-v
paragraph.content: Records from the consumer's employer or a third party that obtained information from the employer;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-4-vi
paragraph.content: Records from a Federal, State, or local government agency stating the consumer's income from benefits or entitlements;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-4-vii
paragraph.content: Receipts from the consumer's use of check cashing services; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-4-viii
paragraph.content: Receipts from the consumer's use of a funds transfer service.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-3
paragraph.title: Verification using third-party records.
paragraph.content: Verification using third-party records. A creditor must verify the information that the creditor relies on in determining a consumer's repayment ability under § 1026.43(c)(2) using reasonably reliable third-party records, except that:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-3-i
paragraph.content: For purposes of paragraph (c)(2)(i) of this section, a creditor must verify a consumer's income or assets that the creditor relies on in accordance with § 1026.43(c)(4);

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-3-ii
paragraph.content: For purposes of paragraph (c)(2)(ii) of this section, a creditor may verify a consumer's employment status orally if the creditor prepares a record of the information obtained orally; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-3-iii
paragraph.content: For purposes of paragraph (c)(2)(vi) of this section, if a creditor relies on a consumer's credit report to verify a consumer's current debt obligations and a consumer's application states a current debt obligation not shown in the consumer's credit report, the creditor need not independently verify such an obligation.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-2
paragraph.title: Basis for determination.
paragraph.content: Basis for determination. Except as provided otherwise in paragraphs (d), (e), and (f) of this section, in making the repayment ability determination required under paragraph (c)(1) of this section, a creditor must consider the following:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-2-i
paragraph.content: The consumer's current or reasonably expected income or assets, other than the value of the dwelling, including any real property attached to the dwelling, that secures the loan;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-2-ii
paragraph.content: If the creditor relies on income from the consumer's employment in determining repayment ability, the consumer's current employment status;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-2-iii
paragraph.content: The consumer's monthly payment on the covered transaction, calculated in accordance with paragraph (c)(5) of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-2-iv
paragraph.content: The consumer's monthly payment on any simultaneous loan that the creditor knows or has reason to know will be made, calculated in accordance with paragraph (c)(6) of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-2-v
paragraph.content: The consumer's monthly payment for mortgage-related obligations;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-2-vi
paragraph.content: The consumer's current debt obligations, alimony, and child support;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-2-vii
paragraph.content: The consumer's monthly debt-to-income ratio or residual income in accordance with paragraph (c)(7) of this section; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-2-viii
paragraph.content: The consumer's credit history.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-1
paragraph.title: General requirement.
paragraph.content: General requirement. A creditor shall not make a loan that is a covered transaction unless the creditor makes a reasonable and good faith determination at or before consummation that the consumer will have a reasonable ability to repay the loan according to its terms.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-vii
paragraph.content: If applicable, a statement that the new payment will not be allocated to pay loan principal and will not reduce the loan balance. If the new payment will result in negative amortization, a statement that the new payment will not be allocated to pay loan principal and will pay only part of the loan interest, thereby adding to the balance of the loan. If the new payment will result in negative amortization as a result of the interest rate adjustment, the statement shall set forth the payment required to amortize fully the remaining balance at the new interest rate over the remainder of the loan term.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1
paragraph.title: Definitions.
paragraph.content: Definitions. For purposes of this paragraph (d), the following definitions apply:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-i
paragraph.title: Non-standard mortgage.
paragraph.content: Non-standard mortgage. The term non-standard mortgage means a covered transaction that is:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-i-A
paragraph.content: An adjustable-rate mortgage, as defined in § 1026.18(s)(7)(i), with an introductory fixed interest rate for a period of one year or longer;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-i-B
paragraph.content: An interest-only loan, as defined in § 1026.18(s)(7)(iv); or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-i-C
paragraph.content: A negative amortization loan, as defined in § 1026.18(s)(7)(v).

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii
paragraph.title: Standard mortgage.
paragraph.content: Standard mortgage. The term standard mortgage means a covered transaction:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-A
paragraph.content: That provides for regular periodic payments that do not:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-A-1
paragraph.content: Cause the principal balance to increase;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-A-2
paragraph.content: Allow the consumer to defer repayment of principal; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-A-3
paragraph.content: Result in a balloon payment, as defined in § 1026.18(s)(5)(i);

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-B
paragraph.content: For which the total points and fees payable in connection with the transaction do not exceed the amounts specified in paragraph (e)(3) of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-C
paragraph.content: For which the term does not exceed 40 years;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-D
paragraph.content: For which the interest rate is fixed for at least the first five years after consummation; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-E
paragraph.content: For which the proceeds from the loan are used solely for the following purposes:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-E-1
paragraph.content: To pay off the outstanding principal balance on the non-standard mortgage; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-E-2
paragraph.content: To pay closing or settlement charges required to be disclosed under the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act, 12 U.S.C. 2601 et seq.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-iii
paragraph.title: Refinancing.
paragraph.content: Refinancing. The term refinancing has the same meaning as in § 1026.20(a).

paragraph.label: 1026-32-d-6
paragraph.title: Prepayment penalties.
paragraph.content: Prepayment penalties. Except as allowed under paragraph (d)(7) of this section, a penalty for paying all or part of the principal before the date on which the principal is due. A prepayment penalty includes computing a refund of unearned interest by a method that is less favorable to the consumer than the actuarial method, as defined by section 933(d) of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1992, 15 U.S.C. 1615(d).

paragraph.label: 1026-32-d-7
paragraph.title: Prepayment penalty exception.
paragraph.content: Prepayment penalty exception. A mortgage transaction subject to this section may provide for a prepayment penalty (including a refund calculated according to the rule of 78s) otherwise permitted by law if, under the terms of the loan:

paragraph.label: 1026-32-d-7-i
paragraph.content: The penalty will not apply after the two-year period following consummation;

paragraph.label: 1026-32-d-7-ii
paragraph.content: The penalty will not apply if the source of the prepayment funds is a refinancing by the creditor or an affiliate of the creditor;

paragraph.label: 1026-32-d-7-iii
paragraph.content: At consummation, the consumer's total monthly debt payments (including amounts owed under the mortgage) do not exceed 50 percent of the consumer's monthly gross income, as verified in accordance with § 1026.34(a)(4)(ii); and

paragraph.label: 1026-32-d-7-iv
paragraph.content: The amount of the periodic payment of principal or interest or both may not change during the four-year period following consummation.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-4
paragraph.title: Offer of rate discounts and other favorable terms.
paragraph.content: Offer of rate discounts and other favorable terms. A creditor making a covered transaction under this paragraph (d) may offer to the consumer rate discounts and terms that are the same as, or better than, the rate discounts and terms that the creditor offers to new consumers, consistent with the creditor's documented underwriting practices and to the extent not prohibited by applicable State or Federal law.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2-i
paragraph.content: Dual compensation.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2-i-A
paragraph.content: Except as provided in paragraph (d)(2)(i)(C) of this section, if any loan originator receives compensation directly from a consumer in a consumer credit transaction secured by a dwelling:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2-i-A-1
paragraph.content: No loan originator shall receive compensation, directly or indirectly, from any person other than the consumer in connection with the transaction; and

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2-i-A-2
paragraph.content: No person who knows or has reason to know of the consumer-paid compensation to the loan originator (other than the consumer) shall pay any compensation to a loan originator, directly or indirectly, in connection with the transaction.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2-i-B
paragraph.content: Compensation received directly from a consumer includes payments to a loan originator made pursuant to an agreement between the consumer and a person other than the creditor or its affiliates, under which such other person agrees to provide funds toward the consumer's costs of the transaction (including loan originator compensation).

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2-i-C
paragraph.content: If a loan originator organization receives compensation directly from a consumer in connection with a transaction, the loan originator organization may pay compensation to an individual loan originator, and the individual loan originator may receive compensation from the loan originator organization, subject to paragraph (d)(1) of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-iv
paragraph.content: Any limits on the interest rate or payment increases at each interest rate adjustment and over the life of the loan, as applicable, including the extent to which such limits result in the creditor, assignee, or servicer foregoing any increase in the interest rate and the earliest date that such foregone interest rate increases may apply to future interest rate adjustments, subject to those limits.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-iii
paragraph.content: A table containing the following information:

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-iii-A
paragraph.content: The current and new interest rates;

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-iii-B
paragraph.content: The current and new payments and the date the first new payment is due; and

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-iii-C
paragraph.content: For interest-only or negatively-amortizing payments, the amount of the current and new payment allocated to principal, interest, and taxes and insurance in escrow, as applicable. The current payment allocation disclosed shall be the payment allocation for the last payment prior to the date of the disclosure. The new payment allocation disclosed shall be the expected payment allocation for the first payment for which the new interest rate will apply.

paragraph.label: 1026-32-d-8
paragraph.title: Due-on-demand clause.
paragraph.content: Due-on-demand clause. A demand feature that permits the creditor to terminate the loan in advance of the original maturity date and to demand repayment of the entire outstanding balance, except in the following circumstances:

paragraph.label: 1026-32-d-8-i
paragraph.content: There is fraud or material misrepresentation by the consumer in connection with the loan;

paragraph.label: 1026-32-d-8-ii
paragraph.content: The consumer fails to meet the repayment terms of the agreement for any outstanding balance; or

paragraph.label: 1026-32-d-8-iii
paragraph.content: There is any action or inaction by the consumer that adversely affects the creditor's security for the loan, or any right of the creditor in such security.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-g-3
paragraph.content: For purposes of this section, NMLSR ID means a number assigned by the Nationwide Mortgage Licensing System and Registry to facilitate electronic tracking and uniform identification of loan originators and public access to the employment history of, and the publicly adjudicated disciplinary and enforcement actions against, loan originators.

paragraph.label: 1026-25-a
paragraph.title: General rule.
paragraph.content: General rule. A creditor shall retain evidence of compliance with this regulation, other than advertising requirements under §§ 1026.16 and 1026.24 and certain requirements for mortgage loans under paragraph (c) of this section, for two years after the date disclosures are required to be made or action is required to be taken. The administrative agencies responsible for enforcing the regulation may require a creditor under their jurisdictions to retain records for a longer period if necessary to carry out their enforcement responsibilities under section 108 of the Act.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-3-ii
paragraph.content: The disclosures required by paragraph (c)(2)(ii) of this section shall be in the form of a table located within the table described in paragraph (c)(3)(i) of this section. These disclosures shall appear in the same order as, and with headings and format substantially similar to, the table inside the larger table in forms H-4(D)(1) and (2) in appendix H to this part.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-viii
paragraph.content: The circumstances under which any prepayment penalty, as defined in § 1026.32(b)(6)(i), may be imposed, such as when paying the loan in full or selling or refinancing the principal dwelling; the time period during which such a penalty may be imposed; and a statement that the consumer may contact the servicer for additional information, including the maximum amount of the penalty.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-v
paragraph.content: Notwithstanding paragraph (b)(2)(iii) of this section, an escrow account must be established pursuant to paragraph (b)(1) of this section for any first-lien higher-priced mortgage loan that, at consummation, is subject to a commitment to be acquired by a person that does not satisfy the conditions in paragraph (b)(2)(iii) of this section, unless otherwise exempted by this paragraph (b)(2).

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-2-iii
paragraph.content: The consumer's monthly payment on the covered transaction, calculated in accordance with paragraph (c)(5) of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-3
paragraph.title: Alternative offer required.
paragraph.content: Alternative offer required. A creditor must not offer a consumer a covered transaction with a prepayment penalty unless the creditor also offers the consumer an alternative covered transaction without a prepayment penalty and the alternative covered transaction:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-3-i
paragraph.content: Has an annual percentage rate that cannot increase after consummation and has the same type of interest rate as the covered transaction with a prepayment penalty; for purposes of this paragraph (g), the term “type of interest rate” refers to whether a transaction:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-3-i-A
paragraph.content: Is a fixed-rate mortgage, as defined in § 1026.18(s)(7)(iii); or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-3-i-B
paragraph.content: Is a step-rate mortgage, as defined in § 1026.18(s)(7)(ii);

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-3-ii
paragraph.content: Has the same loan term as the loan term for the covered transaction with a prepayment penalty;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-3-iii
paragraph.content: Satisfies the periodic payment conditions under paragraph (e)(2)(i) of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-3-iv
paragraph.content: Satisfies the points and fees conditions under paragraph (e)(2)(iii) of this section, based on the information known to the creditor at the time the transaction is offered; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-3-v
paragraph.content: Is a transaction for which the creditor has a good faith belief that the consumer likely qualifies, based on the information known to the creditor at the time the creditor offers the covered transaction without a prepayment penalty.

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-3-i
paragraph.title: Closed-end credit.
paragraph.content: Closed-end credit. The term bona fide discount point means an amount equal to 1 percent of the loan amount paid by the consumer that reduces the interest rate or time-price differential applicable to the transaction based on a calculation that is consistent with established industry practices for determining the amount of reduction in the interest rate or time-price differential appropriate for the amount of discount points paid by the consumer.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-1
paragraph.title: When permitted.
paragraph.content: When permitted. A covered transaction must not include a prepayment penalty unless:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-1-i
paragraph.content: The prepayment penalty is otherwise permitted by law; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-1-ii
paragraph.content: The transaction:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-1-ii-A
paragraph.content: Has an annual percentage rate that cannot increase after consummation;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-1-ii-B
paragraph.content: Is a qualified mortgage under paragraph (e)(2), (e)(4), (e)(5), (e)(6), or (f) of this section; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-1-ii-C
paragraph.content: Is not a higher-priced mortgage loan, as defined in § 1026.35(a).

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-ii
paragraph.content: Determine on the basis of the information obtained pursuant to paragraph (f)(3)(i) of this section and any other information reasonably available to the loan originator organization, for any individual whom the loan originator organization hired on or after January 10, 2014 (or whom the loan originator organization hired before this date but for whom there were no applicable statutory or regulatory background standards in effect at the time of hire or before January 10, 2014, used to screen the individual) and for any individual regardless of when hired who, based on reliable information known to the loan originator organization, likely does not meet the standards under this § 1026.36(f)(3)(ii), before the individual acts as a loan originator in a consumer credit transaction secured by a dwelling, that the individual loan originator:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-ii-A-1
paragraph.content: Has not been convicted of, or pleaded guilty or nolo contendere to, a felony in a domestic or military court during the preceding seven-year period or, in the case of a felony involving an act of fraud, dishonesty, a breach of trust, or money laundering, at any time;

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-ii-A-2
paragraph.content: For purposes of this paragraph (f)(3)(ii)(A):

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-ii-A-2-i
paragraph.content: A crime is a felony only if at the time of conviction it was classified as a felony under the law of the jurisdiction under which the individual was convicted;

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-ii-A-2-ii
paragraph.content: Expunged convictions and pardoned convictions do not render an individual unqualified; and

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-ii-A-2-iii
paragraph.content: A conviction or plea of guilty or nolo contendere does not render an individual unqualified under this § 1026.36(f) if the loan originator organization has obtained consent to employ the individual from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (or the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, as applicable) pursuant to section 19 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act (FDIA), 12 U.S.C. 1829, the National Credit Union Administration pursuant to section 205 of the Federal Credit Union Act (FCUA), 12 U.S.C. 1785(d), or the Farm Credit Administration pursuant to section 5.65(d) of the Farm Credit Act of 1971 (FCA), 12 U.S.C. 227a-14(d), notwithstanding the bars posed with respect to that conviction or plea by the FDIA, FCUA, and FCA, as applicable; and

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-ii-B
paragraph.content: Has demonstrated financial responsibility, character, and general fitness such as to warrant a determination that the individual loan originator will operate honestly, fairly, and efficiently; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-2-ii
paragraph.content: The monthly payment for the standard mortgage is materially lower than the monthly payment for the non-standard mortgage, as calculated under paragraph (d)(5) of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-5
paragraph.title: Creditor that is a loan originator.
paragraph.content: Creditor that is a loan originator. If the creditor is a loan originator, as defined in § 1026.36(a)(1), and the creditor presents the consumer a covered transaction offered by a person to which the creditor would assign the covered transaction after consummation, the creditor must present the consumer an alternative covered transaction without a prepayment penalty that satisfies the requirements of paragraph (g)(3) of this section, offered by:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-5-i
paragraph.content: The assignee; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-5-ii
paragraph.content: Another person, if the transaction offered by the other person has a lower interest rate or a lower total dollar amount of origination discount points and points or fees.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-4
paragraph.title: Offer through a mortgage broker.
paragraph.content: Offer through a mortgage broker. If the creditor offers a covered transaction with a prepayment penalty to the consumer through a mortgage broker, as defined in § 1026.36(a)(2), the creditor must:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-4-i
paragraph.content: Present the mortgage broker an alternative covered transaction without a prepayment penalty that satisfies the requirements of paragraph (g)(3) of this section; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-4-ii
paragraph.content: Establish by agreement that the mortgage broker must present the consumer an alternative covered transaction without a prepayment penalty that satisfies the requirements of paragraph (g)(3) of this section, offered by:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-4-ii-A
paragraph.content: The creditor; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-4-ii-B
paragraph.content: Another creditor, if the transaction offered by the other creditor has a lower interest rate or a lower total dollar amount of discount points and origination points or fees.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-vi
paragraph.content: For which the ratio of the consumer's total monthly debt to total monthly income at the time of consummation does not exceed 43 percent. For purposes of this paragraph (e)(2)(vi), the ratio of the consumer's total monthly debt to total monthly income is determined:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-vi-A
paragraph.content: Except as provided in paragraph (e)(2)(vi)(B) of this section, in accordance with the standards in appendix Q;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-vi-B
paragraph.content: Using the consumer's monthly payment on:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-vi-B-1
paragraph.content: The covered transaction, including the monthly payment for mortgage-related obligations, in accordance with paragraph (e)(2)(iv) of this section; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-vi-B-2
paragraph.content: Any simultaneous loan that the creditor knows or has reason to know will be made, in accordance with paragraphs (c)(2)(iv) and (c)(6) of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-ix
paragraph.content: The telephone number of the creditor, assignee, or servicer for consumers to call if they anticipate not being able to make their new payments.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-11
paragraph.content: Recast means:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-11-i
paragraph.content: For an adjustable-rate mortgage, as defined in § 1026.18(s)(7)(i), the expiration of the period during which payments based on the introductory fixed interest rate are permitted under the terms of the legal obligation;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-11-ii
paragraph.content: For an interest-only loan, as defined in § 1026.18(s)(7)(iv), the expiration of the period during which interest-only payments are permitted under the terms of the legal obligation; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-11-iii
paragraph.content: For a negative amortization loan, as defined in § 1026.18(s)(7)(v), the expiration of the period during which negatively amortizing payments are permitted under the terms of the legal obligation.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-12
paragraph.content: Simultaneous loan means another covered transaction or home equity line of credit subject to § 1026.40 that will be secured by the same dwelling and made to the same consumer at or before consummation of the covered transaction or, if to be made after consummation, will cover closing costs of the first covered transaction.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-13
paragraph.content: Third-party record means:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-13-i
paragraph.content: A document or other record prepared or reviewed by an appropriate person other than the consumer, the creditor, or the mortgage broker, as defined in § 1026.36(a)(2), or an agent of the creditor or mortgage broker;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-13-ii
paragraph.content: A copy of a tax return filed with the Internal Revenue Service or a State taxing authority;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-13-iii
paragraph.content: A record the creditor maintains for an account of the consumer held by the creditor; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-13-iv
paragraph.content: If the consumer is an employee of the creditor or the mortgage broker, a document or other record maintained by the creditor or mortgage broker regarding the consumer's employment status or employment income.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-c
paragraph.content: [Reserved]

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-iv
paragraph.content: An explanation of how the interest rate is determined, including:

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-iv-A
paragraph.content: The specific index or formula used in making interest rate adjustments and a source of information about the index or formula; and

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-iv-B
paragraph.content: The type and amount of any adjustment to the index, including any margin and an explanation that the margin is the addition of a certain number of percentage points to the index.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii
paragraph.title: Standard mortgage.
paragraph.content: Standard mortgage. The term standard mortgage means a covered transaction:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-A
paragraph.content: That provides for regular periodic payments that do not:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-A-1
paragraph.content: Cause the principal balance to increase;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-A-2
paragraph.content: Allow the consumer to defer repayment of principal; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-A-3
paragraph.content: Result in a balloon payment, as defined in § 1026.18(s)(5)(i);

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-B
paragraph.content: For which the total points and fees payable in connection with the transaction do not exceed the amounts specified in paragraph (e)(3) of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-C
paragraph.content: For which the term does not exceed 40 years;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-D
paragraph.content: For which the interest rate is fixed for at least the first five years after consummation; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-E
paragraph.content: For which the proceeds from the loan are used solely for the following purposes:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-E-1
paragraph.content: To pay off the outstanding principal balance on the non-standard mortgage; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-E-2
paragraph.content: To pay closing or settlement charges required to be disclosed under the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act, 12 U.S.C. 2601 et seq.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-xi
paragraph.content: The Web site to access either the Bureau list or the HUD list of homeownership counselors and counseling organizations, the HUD toll-free telephone number to access the HUD list of homeownership counselors and counseling organizations, and the Bureau Web site to access contact information for State housing finance authorities (as defined in § 1301 of the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act of 1989).

paragraph.label: 1026-35-d
paragraph.title: Evasion; open-end credit.
paragraph.content: Evasion; open-end credit. In connection with credit secured by a consumer's principal dwelling that does not meet the definition of open-end credit in § 1026.2(a)(20), a creditor shall not structure a home-secured loan as an open-end plan to evade the requirements of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-e
paragraph.title: Repayment ability, prepayment penalties.
paragraph.content: Repayment ability, prepayment penalties. Higher-priced mortgage loans are subject to the following restrictions:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-e-1
paragraph.title: Repayment ability.
paragraph.content: Repayment ability. A creditor shall not extend credit based on the value of the consumer's collateral without regard to the consumer's repayment ability as of consummation as provided in § 1026.34(a)(4).

paragraph.label: 1026-35-e-2
paragraph.title: Prepayment penalties.
paragraph.content: Prepayment penalties. A loan may not include a penalty described by § 1026.32(d)(6) unless:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-e-2-i
paragraph.content: The penalty is otherwise permitted by law, including § 1026.32(d)(7) if the loan is a mortgage transaction described in § 1026.32(a); and

paragraph.label: 1026-35-e-2-ii
paragraph.content: Under the terms of the loan:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-e-2-ii-A
paragraph.content: The penalty will not apply after the two-year period following consummation;

paragraph.label: 1026-35-e-2-ii-B
paragraph.content: The penalty will not apply if the source of the prepayment funds is a refinancing by the creditor or an affiliate of the creditor; and

paragraph.label: 1026-35-e-2-ii-C
paragraph.content: The amount of the periodic payment of principal or interest or both may not change during the four-year period following consummation.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-e-4
paragraph.content: Sunset of requirements on repayment ability and prepayment penalties. The requirements described in this paragraph (e) shall expire at 11:59 p.m. on January 9, 2014.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-c-1-i
paragraph.content: Periodic payments. No servicer shall fail to credit a periodic payment to the consumer's loan account as of the date of receipt, except when a delay in crediting does not result in any charge to the consumer or in the reporting of negative information to a consumer reporting agency, or except as provided in paragraph (c)(1)(iii) of this section. A periodic payment, as used in this paragraph (c), is an amount sufficient to cover principal, interest, and escrow (if applicable) for a given billing cycle. A payment qualifies as a periodic payment even if it does not include amounts required to cover late fees, other fees, or non-escrow payments a servicer has advanced on a consumer's behalf.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-2-iv
paragraph.content: The consumer's monthly payment on any simultaneous loan that the creditor knows or has reason to know will be made, calculated in accordance with paragraph (c)(6) of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-ii
paragraph.content: A statement providing:

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-ii-A
paragraph.content: An explanation that under the terms of the consumer's adjustable-rate mortgage, the specific time period in which the current interest rate has been in effect is ending and that any change in the interest rate may result in a change in the mortgage payment;

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-ii-B
paragraph.content: The effective date of the interest rate adjustment and when additional future interest rate adjustments are scheduled to occur; and

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-ii-C
paragraph.content: Any other changes to loan terms, features, or options taking effect on the same date as the interest rate adjustment, such as the expiration of interest-only or payment-option features.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-2-vi
paragraph.content: The consumer's current debt obligations, alimony, and child support;

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-2-ii
paragraph.content: All compensation paid directly or indirectly by a consumer or creditor to a loan originator, as defined in § 1026.36(a)(1), that can be attributed to that transaction at the time the interest rate is set unless:

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-2-ii-A
paragraph.content: That compensation is paid by a consumer to a mortgage broker, as defined in § 1026.36(a)(2), and already has been included in points and fees under paragraph (b)(2)(i) of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-2-ii-B
paragraph.content: That compensation is paid by a mortgage broker, as defined in § 1026.36(a)(2), to a loan originator that is an employee of the mortgage broker; or

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-2-ii-C
paragraph.content: That compensation is paid by a creditor to a loan originator that is an employee of the creditor.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-c-3
paragraph.content: Payoff statements. In connection with a consumer credit transaction secured by a consumer's dwelling, a creditorr, assignee or servicer, as applicable, must provide an accurate statement of the total outstanding balance that would be required to pay the consumer's obligation in full as of a specified date. The statement shall be sent within a reasonable time, but in no case more than seven business days, after receiving a written request from the consumer or any person acting on behalf of the consumer. When a creditor, assignee, or servicer, as applicable, is not able to provide the statement within seven business days of such a request because a loan is in bankruptcy or foreclosure, because the loan is a reverse mortgage or shared appreciation mortgage, or because of natural disasters or other similar circumstances, the payoff statement must be provided within a reasonable time. A creditor or assignee that does not currently own the mortgage loan or the mortgage servicing rights is not subject to the requirement in this paragraph (c)(3) to provide a payoff statement.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-c-2
paragraph.content: No pyramiding of late fees. In connection with a consumer credit transaction secured by a consumer's principal dwelling, a servicer shall not impose any late fee or delinquency charge for a payment if:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-c-2-i
paragraph.content: Such a fee or charge is attributable solely to failure of the consumer to pay a late fee or delinquency charge on an earlier payment; and

paragraph.label: 1026-36-c-2-ii
paragraph.content: The payment is otherwise a periodic payment received on the due date, or within any applicable courtesy period.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1
paragraph.title: Payments based on transaction terms or conditions.
paragraph.content: Payments based on a term of a transaction.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-i
paragraph.content: Except as provided in paragraph (d)(1)(iii) or (iv) of this section, in connection with a consumer credit transaction secured by a dwelling, no loan originator shall receive and no person shall pay to a loan originator, directly or indirectly, compensation in an amount that is based on a term of a transaction, the terms of multiple transactions by an individual loan originator, or the terms of multiple transactions by multiple individual loan originators. If a loan originator's compensation is based in whole or in part on a factor that is a proxy for a term of a transaction, the loan originator's compensation is based on a term of a transaction. A factor that is not itself a term of a transaction is a proxy for a term of the transaction if the factor consistently varies with that term over a significant number of transactions, and the loan originator has the ability, directly or indirectly, to add, drop, or change the factor in originating the transaction.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-ii
paragraph.content: For purposes of this paragraph (d)(1) only, a “term of a transaction” is any right or obligation of the parties to a credit transaction. The amount of credit extended is not a term of a transaction or a proxy for a term of a transaction, provided that compensation received by or paid to a loan originator, directly or indirectly, is based on a fixed percentage of the amount of credit extended; however, such compensation may be subject to a minimum or maximum dollar amount.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-iii
paragraph.content: An individual loan originatoroan originator may receive, and a person may pay to an individual loan originatordual loan originator, compensation in the form of a contribution to a defined contribution plan that is a designated tax-advantaged plan or a benefit under a defined benefit plan that is a designated tax-advantaged plan. In the case of a contribution to a defined contribution plan, the contribution shall not be directly or indirectly based on the terms of that individual loan originator's transactions. As used in this paragraph (d)(1)(iii), “designated tax-advantaged plan” means any plan that meets the requirements of Internal Revenue Code section 401(a), 26 U.S.C. 401(a); employee annuity plan described in Internal Revenue Code section 403(a), 26 U.S.C. 403(a); simple retirement account, as defined in Internal Revenue Code section 408(p), 26 U.S.C. 408(p); simplified employee pension described in Internal Revenue Code section 408(k), 26 U.S.C. 408(k); annuity contract described in Internal Revenue Code section 403(b), 26 U.S.C. 403(b); or eligible deferred compensation plan, as defined in Internal Revenue Code section 457(b), 26 U.S.C. 457(b).

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-iv
paragraph.content: An individual loan originator may receive, and a person may pay to an individual loan originator, compensation under a non-deferred profits-based compensation plan (i.e., any arrangement for the payment of non-deferred compensation that is determined with reference to the profits of the person from mortgage-related business), provided that:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-iv-A
paragraph.content: The compensation paid to an individual loan originator pursuant to this paragraph (d)(1)(iv) is not directly or indirectly based on the terms of that individual loan originator's transactions that are subject to this paragraph (d); and

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-iv-B
paragraph.content: At least one of the following conditions is satisfied:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-iv-B-1
paragraph.content: The compensation paid to an individual loan originator pursuant to this paragraph (d)(1)(iv) does not, in the aggregate, exceed 10 percent of the individual loan originator's total compensation corresponding to the time period for which the compensation under the non-deferred profits-based compensation plan is paid; or

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-iv-B-2
paragraph.content: The individual loan originator was a loan originator for ten or fewer transactions subject to this paragraph (d) consummated during the 12-month period preceding the date of the compensation determination.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-C
paragraph.content: A negative amortization loan, as defined in § 1026.18(s)(7)(v), using:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-C-1
paragraph.content: The fully indexed rate or any introductory interest rate, whichever is greater; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-C-2
paragraph.content: Substantially equal, monthly payments of principal and interest that will repay the maximum loan amount over the term of the loan remaining as of the date the loan is recast.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-B
paragraph.content: An interest-only loan, as defined in § 1026.18(s)(7)(iv), using:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-B-1
paragraph.content: The fully indexed rate or any introductory interest rate, whichever is greater; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-B-2
paragraph.content: Substantially equal, monthly payments of principal and interest that will repay the loan amount over the term of the loan remaining as of the date the loan is recast.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2-ii
paragraph.content: Exemption. A payment to a loan originator that is otherwise prohibited by section 129B(c)(2)(A) of the Truth in Lending Act is nevertheless permitted pursuant to section 129B(c)(2)(B) of the Act, regardless of whether the consumer makes any upfront payment of discount points, origination points, or fees, as described in section 129B(c)(2)(B)(ii) of the Act, as long as the loan originator does not receive any compensation directly from the consumer as described in section 129B(c)(2)(B)(i) of the Act.

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i
paragraph.content: All items included in the finance charge under § 1026.4(a) and (b), except that the following items are excluded:

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-A
paragraph.content: Interest or the time-price differential;

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-B
paragraph.content: Any premium or other charge imposed in connection with any Federal or State agency program for any guaranty or insurance that protects the creditor against the consumer's default or other credit loss;

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-C
paragraph.content: For any guaranty or insurance that protects the creditor against the consumer's default or other credit loss and that is not in connection with any Federal or State agency program:

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-C-1
paragraph.content: If the premium or other charge is payable after consummation, the entire amount of such premium or other charge; or

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-C-2
paragraph.content: If the premium or other charge is payable at or before consummation, the portion of any such premium or other charge that is not in excess of the amount payable under policies in effect at the time of origination under section 203(c)(2)(A) of the National Housing Act (12 U.S.C. 1709(c)(2)(A)), provided that the premium or charge is required to be refundable on a pro rata basis and the refund is automatically issued upon notification of the satisfaction of the underlying mortgage loan;

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-D
paragraph.content: Any bona fide third-party charge not retained by the creditor, loan originator, or an affiliate of either, unless the charge is required to be included in points and fees under paragraph (b)(1)(i)(C), (iii), or (iv) of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-E
paragraph.content: Up to two bona fide discount points paid by the consumer in connection with the transaction, if the interest rate without any discount does not exceed:

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-E-1
paragraph.content: The average prime offer rate, as defined in § 1026.35(a)(2), by more than one percentage point; or

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-E-2
paragraph.content: For purposes of paragraph (a)(1)(ii) of this section, for transactions that are secured by personal property, the average rate for a loan insured under Title I of the National Housing Act (12 U.S.C. 1702 et seq.) by more than one percentage point; and

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-F
paragraph.content: If no discount points have been excluded under paragraph (b)(1)(i)(E) of this section, then up to one bona fide discount point paid by the consumer in connection with the transaction, if the interest rate without any discount does not exceed:

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-F-1
paragraph.content: The average prime offer rate, as defined in § 1026.35(a)(2), by more than two percentage points; or

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-F-2
paragraph.content: For purposes of paragraph (a)(1)(ii) of this section, for transactions that are secured by personal property, the average rate for a loan insured under Title I of the National Housing Act (12 U.S.C. 1702 et seq.) by more than two percentage points;

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-6-i
paragraph.title: Closed-end credit transactions.
paragraph.content: Closed-end credit transactions. For a closed-end credit transaction, prepayment penalty means a charge imposed for paying all or part of the transaction's principal before the date on which the principal is due, other than a waived, bona fide third-party charge that the creditor imposes if the consumer prepays all of the transaction's principal sooner than 36 months after consummation, provided, however, that interest charged consistent with the monthly interest accrual amortization method is not a prepayment penalty for extensions of credit insured by the Federal Housing Administration that are consummated before January 21, 2015.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-iv-A
paragraph.content: The compensation paid to an individual loan originator pursuant to this paragraph (d)(1)(iv) is not directly or indirectly based on the terms of that individual loan originator's transactions that are subject to this paragraph (d); and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-2-vii
paragraph.content: The consumer's monthly debt-to-income ratio or residual income in accordance with paragraph (c)(7) of this section; and

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-1-ii
paragraph.title: Exemptions.
paragraph.content: Exemptions. The requirements of this paragraph (d) do not apply to ARMs with terms of one year or less.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-6-i
paragraph.content: A covered transaction, by following paragraph (c)(5)of this section; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-2-iv
paragraph.content: The consumer has made no more than one payment more than 30 days late on the non-standard mortgage during the 12 months immediately preceding the creditor's receipt of the consumer's written application for the standard mortgage.

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-v
paragraph.content: The maximum prepayment penalty, as defined in paragraph (b)(6)(i) of this section, that may be charged or collected under the terms of the mortgage loan; and

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-i
paragraph.content: Obtain for any individual whom the loan originator organization hired on or after January 10, 2014 (or whom the loan originator organization hired before this date but for whom there were no applicable statutory or regulatory background standards in effect at the time of hire or before January 10, 2014, used to screen the individual) and for any individual regardless of when hired who, based on reliable information known to the loan originator organization, likely does not meet the standards under § 1026.36(f)(3)(ii), before the individual acts as a loan originator in a consumer credit transaction secured by a dwelling:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-i-A
paragraph.content: A criminal background check through the Nationwide Mortgage Licensing System and Registry (NMLSR) or, in the case of an individual loan originator who is not a registered loan originator under the NMLSR, a criminal background check from a law enforcement agency or commercial service;

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-i-B
paragraph.content: A credit report from a consumer reporting agency described in section 603(p) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act (15 U.S.C. 1681a(p)) secured, where applicable, in compliance with the requirements of section 604(b) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. 1681b(b); and

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-i-C
paragraph.content: Information from the NMLSR about any administrative, civil, or criminal findings by any government jurisdiction or, in the case of an individual loan originator who is not a registered loan originator under the NMLSR, such information from the individual loan originator;

paragraph.label: 1026-36-c-1-iii
paragraph.content: Non-conforming payments. If a servicer specifies in writing requirements for the consumer to follow in making payments, but accepts a payment that does not conform to the requirements, the servicer shall credit the payment as of five days after receipt.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-v
paragraph.content: An explanation of how the new payment is determined, including:

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-v-A
paragraph.content: The index or formula used;

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-v-B
paragraph.content: Any adjustment to the index or formula, such as the addition of a margin or the application of any previously foregone interest rate increases from past interest rate adjustments;

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-v-C
paragraph.content: The loan balance expected on the date of the interest rate adjustment; and

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-v-D
paragraph.content: The length of the remaining loan term expected on the date of the interest rate adjustment and any change in the term of the loan caused by the adjustment.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-i
paragraph.title: General rule.
paragraph.content: General rule. Except as provided in paragraph (c)(5)(ii) of this section, a creditor must make the consideration required under paragraph (c)(2)(iii) of this section using:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-i-A
paragraph.content: The fully indexed rate or any introductory interest rate, whichever is greater; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-i-B
paragraph.content: Monthly, fully amortizing payments that are substantially equal.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-1-i
paragraph.title: In general.
paragraph.content: In general. For purposes of this paragraph (c), an adjustable-rate mortgage or “ARM” is a closed-end consumer credit transaction secured by the consumer's principal dwelling in which the annual percentage rate may increase after consummation.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-5
paragraph.title: Payment calculations.
paragraph.content: Payment calculations. For purposes of determining whether the consumer's monthly payment for a standard mortgage will be materially lower than the monthly payment for the non-standard mortgage, the following provisions shall be used:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i
paragraph.title: Non-standard mortgage.
paragraph.content: Non-standard mortgage. For purposes of the comparison conducted pursuant to paragraph (d)(2)(ii) of this section, the creditor must calculate the monthly payment for a non-standard mortgage based on substantially equal, monthly, fully amortizing payments of principal and interest using:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i-A
paragraph.content: The fully indexed rate as of a reasonable period of time before or after the date on which the creditor receives the consumer's written application for the standard mortgage;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i-B
paragraph.content: The term of the loan remaining as of the date on which the recast occurs, assuming all scheduled payments have been made up to the recast date and the payment due on the recast date is made and credited as of that date; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i-C
paragraph.content: A remaining loan amount that is:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i-C-1
paragraph.content: For an adjustable-rate mortgage under paragraph (d)(1)(i)(A) of this section, the outstanding principal balance as of the date of the recast, assuming all scheduled payments have been made up to the recast date and the payment due on the recast date is made and credited as of that date;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i-C-2
paragraph.content: For an interest-only loan under paragraph (d)(1)(i)(B) of this section, the outstanding principal balance as of the date of the recast, assuming all scheduled payments have been made up to the recast date and the payment due on the recast date is made and credited as of that date; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i-C-3
paragraph.content: For a negative amortization loan under paragraph (d)(1)(i)(C) of this section, the maximum loan amount, determined after adjusting for the outstanding principal balance.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-ii
paragraph.title: Standard mortgage.
paragraph.content: Standard mortgage. For purposes of the comparison conducted pursuant to paragraph (d)(2)(ii) of this section, the monthly payment for a standard mortgage must be based on substantially equal, monthly, fully amortizing payments based on the maximum interest rate that may apply during the first five years after consummation.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-ii-B
paragraph.content: Has demonstrated financial responsibility, character, and general fitness such as to warrant a determination that the individual loan originator will operate honestly, fairly, and efficiently; and

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-vi
paragraph.content: If applicable, a statement that the new payment will not be allocated to pay loan principal and will not reduce the loan balance. If the new payment will result in negative amortization, a statement that the new payment will not be allocated to pay loan principal and will pay only part of the loan interest, thereby adding to the balance of the loan. If the new payment will result in negative amortization as a result of the interest rate adjustment, the statement shall set forth the payment required to amortize fully the remaining balance at the new interest rate over the remainder of the loan term.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-ii-A-1
paragraph.content: Has not been convicted of, or pleaded guilty or nolo contendere to, a felony in a domestic or military court during the preceding seven-year period or, in the case of a felony involving an act of fraud, dishonesty, a breach of trust, or money laundering, at any time;

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-ii-A-2
paragraph.content: For purposes of this paragraph (f)(3)(ii)(A):

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-ii-A-2-i
paragraph.content: A crime is a felony only if at the time of conviction it was classified as a felony under the law of the jurisdiction under which the individual was convicted;

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-ii-A-2-ii
paragraph.content: Expunged convictions and pardoned convictions do not render an individual unqualified; and

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-ii-A-2-iii
paragraph.content: A conviction or plea of guilty or nolo contendere does not render an individual unqualified under this § 1026.36(f) if the loan originator organization has obtained consent to employ the individual from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (or the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, as applicable) pursuant to section 19 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act (FDIA), 12 U.S.C. 1829, the National Credit Union Administration pursuant to section 205 of the Federal Credit Union Act (FCUA), 12 U.S.C. 1785(d), or the Farm Credit Administration pursuant to section 5.65(d) of the Farm Credit Act of 1971 (FCA), 12 U.S.C. 227a-14(d), notwithstanding the bars posed with respect to that conviction or plea by the FDIA, FCUA, and FCA, as applicable; and

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d
paragraph.content: Initial rate adjustment. The creditor, assignee, or servicer of an adjustable-rate mortgage shall provide consumers with disclosures, as described in this paragraph (d), in connection with the initial interest rate adjustment pursuant to the loan contract. To the extent that other provisions of this subpart C govern the disclosures required by this paragraph (d), those provisions apply to assignees and servicers as well as to creditors. The disclosures required by this paragraph (d) shall be provided as a separate document from other documents provided by the creditor, assignee, or servicer. The disclosures shall be provided to consumers at least 210, but no more than 240, days before the first payment at the adjusted level is due. If the first payment at the adjusted level is due within the first 210 days after consummation, the disclosures shall be provided at consummation.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-1
paragraph.title: Coverage.
paragraph.content: Coverage.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-1-i
paragraph.title: In general.
paragraph.content: In general. For purposes of this paragraph (d), an adjustable-rate mortgage or “ARM” is a closed-end consumer credit transaction secured by the consumer's principal dwelling in which the annual percentage rate may increase after consummation.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-1-ii
paragraph.title: Exemptions.
paragraph.content: Exemptions. The requirements of this paragraph (d) do not apply to ARMs with terms of one year or less.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2
paragraph.title: Content.
paragraph.content: Content. If the new interest rate (or the new payment calculated from the new interest rate) is not known as of the date of the disclosure, an estimate shall be disclosed and labeled as such. This estimate shall be based on the calculation of the index reported in the source of information described in paragraph (d)(2)(iv)(A) of this section within fifteen business days prior to the date of the disclosure. The disclosures required by this paragraph (d) shall include:

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-i
paragraph.content: The date of the disclosure.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-ii
paragraph.content: A statement providing:

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-ii-A
paragraph.content: An explanation that under the terms of the consumer's adjustable-rate mortgage, the specific time period in which the current interest rate has been in effect is ending and that any change in the interest rate may result in a change in the mortgage payment;

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-ii-B
paragraph.content: The effective date of the interest rate adjustment and when additional future interest rate adjustments are scheduled to occur; and

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-ii-C
paragraph.content: Any other changes to loan terms, features, or options taking effect on the same date as the interest rate adjustment, such as the expiration of interest-only or payment-option features.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-iii
paragraph.content: A table containing the following information:

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-iii-A
paragraph.content: The current and new interest rates;

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-iii-B
paragraph.content: The current and new payments and the date the first new payment is due; and

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-iii-C
paragraph.content: For interest-only or negatively-amortizing payments, the amount of the current and new payment allocated to principal, interest, and taxes and insurance in escrow, as applicable. The current payment allocation disclosed shall be the payment allocation for the last payment prior to the date of the disclosure. The new payment allocation disclosed shall be the expected payment allocation for the first payment for which the new interest rate will apply.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-iv
paragraph.content: An explanation of how the interest rate is determined, including:

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-iv-A
paragraph.content: The specific index or formula used in making interest rate adjustments and a source of information about the index or formula; and

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-iv-B
paragraph.content: The type and amount of any adjustment to the index, including any margin and an explanation that the margin is the addition of a certain number of percentage points to the index.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-v
paragraph.content: Any limits on the interest rate or payment increases at each interest rate adjustment and over the life of the loan, as applicable, including the extent to which such limits result in the creditor, assignee, or servicer foregoing any increase in the interest rate and the earliest date that such foregone interest rate increases may apply to future interest rate adjustments, subject to those limits.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-vi
paragraph.content: An explanation of how the new payment is determined, including:

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-vi-A
paragraph.content: The index or formula used;

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-vi-B
paragraph.content: Any adjustment to the index or formula, such as the addition of a margin;

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-vi-C
paragraph.content: The loan balance expected on the date of the interest rate adjustment;

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-vi-D
paragraph.content: The length of the remaining loan term expected on the date of the interest rate adjustment and any change in the term of the loan caused by the adjustment; and

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-vi-E
