If the consumer is more than 45 days delinquent, the following items, grouped together in close proximity to each other and located on the first page of the statement or, alternatively, on a separate page enclosed with the periodic statement or in a separate letter:

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-8-i
paragraph.content: The date on which the consumer became delinquent;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-8-ii
paragraph.content: A notification of possible risks, such as foreclosure, and expenses, that may be incurred if the delinquency is not cured;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-8-iii
paragraph.content: An account history showing, for the previous six months or the period since the last time the account was current, whichever is shorter, the amount remaining past due from each billing cycle or, if any such payment was fully paid, the date on which it was credited as fully paid;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-8-iv
paragraph.content: A notice indicating any loss mitigation program to which the consumer has agreed, if applicable;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-8-v
paragraph.content: A notice of whether the servicer has made the first notice or filing required by applicable law for any judicial or non-judicial foreclosure process, if applicable;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-8-vi
paragraph.content: The total payment amount needed to bring the account current; and

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-8-vii
paragraph.content: A reference to the homeownership counselor information disclosed pursuant to paragraph (d)(7)(v) of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-41-e-4-ii
paragraph.title: Small servicer defined.
paragraph.content: Small servicer defined. A small servicer is a servicer that either:

paragraph.label: 1026-41-e-4-ii-A
paragraph.content: Services 5,000 or fewer mortgage loans, for all of which the servicer (or an affiliate) is the creditor or assignee; or

paragraph.label: 1026-41-e-4-ii-B
paragraph.content: Is a Housing Finance Agency, as defined in 24 CFR 266.5.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-a
paragraph.title: Mortgage transactions subject to RESPA
paragraph.content: Mortgage transactions subject to RESPA —

paragraph.label: 1026-19-a-1-i
paragraph.title: Time of disclosures.
paragraph.content: Time of disclosures. In a mortgage transaction subject to the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act (12 U.S.C. 2601 et seq.) that is secured by the consumer's dwelling, other than a home equity line of credit subject to § 1026.40 or mortgage transaction subject to paragraph (a)(5) of this section, the creditor shall make good faith estimates of the disclosures required by § 1026.18 and shall deliver or place them in the mail not later than the third business day after the creditor receives the consumer's written application.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-a-1-ii
paragraph.title: Imposition of fees.
paragraph.content: Imposition of fees. Except as provided in paragraph (a)(1)(iii) of this section, neither a creditor nor any other person may impose a fee on a consumer in connection with the consumer's application for a mortgage transaction subject to paragraph (a)(1)(i) of this section before the consumer has received the disclosures required by paragraph (a)(1)(i) of this section. If the disclosures are mailed to the consumer, the consumer is considered to have received them three business days after they are mailed.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-a-1-iii
paragraph.title: Exception to fee restriction.
paragraph.content: Exception to fee restriction. A creditor or other person may impose a fee for obtaining the consumer's credit history before the consumer has received the disclosures required by paragraph (a)(1)(i) of this section, provided the fee is bona fide and reasonable in amount.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-a-2
paragraph.title: Waiting periods for early disclosures and corrected disclosures.
paragraph.content: Waiting periods for early disclosures and corrected disclosures.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-a-2-i
paragraph.content: The creditor shall deliver or place in the mail the good faith estimates required by paragraph (a)(1)(i) of this section not later than the seventh business day before consummation of the transaction.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-a-2-ii
paragraph.content: If the annual percentage rate disclosed under paragraph (a)(1)(i) of this section becomes inaccurate, as defined in § 1026.22, the creditor shall provide corrected disclosures with all changed terms. The consumer must receive the corrected disclosures no later than three business days before consummation. If the corrected disclosures are mailed to the consumer or delivered to the consumer by means other than delivery in person, the consumer is deemed to have received the corrected disclosures three business days after they are mailed or delivered.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-a-3
paragraph.title: Consumer's waiver of waiting period before consummation.
paragraph.content: Consumer's waiver of waiting period before consummation. If the consumer determines that the extension of credit is needed to meet a bona fide personal financial emergency, the consumer may modify or waive the seven-business-day waiting period or the three-business-day waiting period required by paragraph (a)(2) of this section, after receiving the disclosures required by § 1026.18. To modify or waive a waiting period, the consumer shall give the creditor a dated written statement that describes the emergency, specifically modifies or waives the waiting period, and bears the signature of all the consumers who are primarily liable on the legal obligation. Printed forms for this purpose are prohibited.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-a-4
paragraph.title: Notice.
paragraph.content: Notice. Disclosures made pursuant to paragraph (a)(1) or paragraph (a)(2) of this section shall contain the following statement: “You are not required to complete this agreement merely because you have received these disclosures or signed a loan application.” The disclosure required by this paragraph shall be grouped together with the disclosures required by paragraphs (a)(1) or (a)(2) of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-a-5
paragraph.title: Timeshare plans.
paragraph.content: Timeshare plans. In a mortgage transaction subject to the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act (12 U.S.C. 2601 et seq.) that is secured by a consumer's interest in a timeshare plan described in 11 U.S.C. 101(53(D)):

paragraph.label: 1026-19-a-5-i
paragraph.content: The requirements of paragraphs (a)(1) through (a)(4) of this section do not apply;

paragraph.label: 1026-19-a-5-ii
paragraph.content: The creditor shall make good faith estimates of the disclosures required by § 1026.18 before consummation, or shall deliver or place them in the mail not later than three business days after the creditor receives the consumer's written application, whichever is earlier; and

paragraph.label: 1026-19-a-5-iii
paragraph.content: If the annual percentage rate at the time of consummation varies from the annual percentage rate disclosed under paragraph (a)(5)(ii) of this section by more than 1/8 of 1 percentage point in a regular transaction or more than 1/4 of 1 percentage point in an irregular transaction, as defined in § 1026.22, the creditor shall disclose all the changed terms no later than consummation or settlement.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b
paragraph.title: Certain variable-rate transactions.
paragraph.content: Certain variable-rate transactions. Except as provided in paragraph (d) of this section, if the annual percentage rate may increase after consummation in a transaction secured by the consumer's principal dwelling with a term greater than one year, the following disclosures must be provided at the time an application form is provided or before the consumer pays a non-refundable fee, whichever is earlier (except that the disclosures may be delivered or placed in the mail not later than three business days following receipt of a consumer's application when the application reaches the creditor by telephone, or through an intermediary agent or broker):

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-1
paragraph.content: The booklet titled Consumer Handbook on Adjustable Rate Mortgages, or a suitable substitute.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2
paragraph.content: A loan program disclosure for each variable-rate program in which the consumer expresses an interest. The following disclosures, as applicable, shall be provided:

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-i
paragraph.content: The fact that the interest rate, payment, or term of the loan can change.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-ii
paragraph.content: The index or formula used in making adjustments, and a source of information about the index or formula.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-iii
paragraph.content: An explanation of how the interest rate and payment will be determined, including an explanation of how the index is adjusted, such as by the addition of a margin.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-iv
paragraph.content: A statement that the consumer should ask about the current margin value and current interest rate.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-v
paragraph.content: The fact that the interest rate will be discounted, and a statement that the consumer should ask about the amount of the interest rate discount.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-vi
paragraph.content: The frequency of interest rate and payment changes.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-vii
paragraph.content: Any rules relating to changes in the index, interest rate, payment amount, and outstanding loan balance including, for example, an explanation of interest rate or payment limitations, negative amortization, and interest rate carryover.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-viii
paragraph.content: At the option of the creditor, either of the following:

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-viii-A
paragraph.content: A historical example, based on a $10,000 loan amount, illustrating how payments and the loan balance would have been affected by interest rate changes implemented according to the terms of the loan program disclosure. The example shall reflect the most recent 15 years of index values. The example shall reflect all significant loan program terms, such as negative amortization, interest rate carryover, interest rate discounts, and interest rate and payment limitations, that would have been affected by the index movement during the period.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-viii-B
paragraph.content: The maximum interest rate and payment for a $10,000 loan originated at the initial interest rate (index value plus margin, adjusted by the amount of any discount or premium) in effect as of an identified month and year for the loan program disclosure assuming the maximum periodic increases in rates and payments under the program; and the initial interest rate and payment for that loan and a statement that the periodic payment may increase or decrease substantially depending on changes in the rate.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-ix
paragraph.content: An explanation of how the consumer may calculate the payments for the loan amount to be borrowed based on either:

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-ix-A
paragraph.content: The most recent payment shown in the historical example in paragraph (b)(2)(viii)(A) of this section; or

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-ix-B
paragraph.content: The initial interest rate used to calculate the maximum interest rate and payment in paragraph (b)(2)(viii)(B) of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-x
paragraph.content: The fact that the loan program contains a demand feature.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-xi
paragraph.content: The type of information that will be provided in notices of adjustments and the timing of such notices.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-xii
paragraph.content: A statement that disclosure forms are available for the creditor's other variable-rate loan programs.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-c
paragraph.title: Electronic disclosures.
paragraph.content: Electronic disclosures. For an application that is accessed by the consumer in electronic form, the disclosures required by paragraph (b) of this section may be provided to the consumer in electronic form on or with the application.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-d
paragraph.content: Information provided in accordance with variable-rate regulations of other Federal agencies may be substituted for the disclosures required by paragraph (b) of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii
paragraph.content: Except as provided in paragraph (b)(2)(v) of this section, an escrow account need not be established for a transaction if, at the time of consummation:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-A
paragraph.content: During the preceding calendar year, the creditor extended more than 50 percent of its total covered transactions, as defined by § 1026.43(b)(1), secured by a first lien, on properties that are located in counties that are either “rural” or “underserved,” as set forth in paragraph (b)(2)(iv) of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-B
paragraph.content: During the preceding calendar year, the creditor and its affiliates together originated 500 or fewer covered transactions, as defined by § 1026.43(b)(1), secured by a first lien; and

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-C
paragraph.content: As of the end of the preceding calendar year, the creditor had total assets of less than $2,000,000,000; this asset threshold shall adjust automatically each year, based on the year-to-year change in the average of the Consumer Price Index for Urban Wage Earners and Clerical Workers, not seasonally adjusted, for each 12-month period ending in November, with rounding to the nearest million dollars (see comment 35(b)(2)(iii)-1.iii for the current threshold); and

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-D
paragraph.content: Neither the creditor nor its affiliate maintains an escrow account of the type described in paragraph (b)(1) of this section for any extension of consumer credit secured by real property or a dwelling that the creditor or its affiliate currently services, other than:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-D-1
paragraph.content: Escrow accounts established for first-lien higher-priced mortgage loans on or after April 1, 2010, and before June 1, 2013; or

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-D-2
paragraph.content: Escrow accounts established after consummation as an accommodation to distressed consumers to assist such consumers in avoiding default or foreclosure.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-v
paragraph.content: The loan is not subject, at consummation, to a commitment to be acquired by another person, other than a person that satisfies the requirements of paragraph (f)(1)(vi) of this section; and

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-3
paragraph.title: Past Payment Breakdown.
paragraph.content: Past Payment Breakdown. The following items, grouped together in close proximity to each other and located on the first page of the statement:

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-3-i
paragraph.content: The total of all payments received since the last statement, including a breakdown showing the amount, if any, that was applied to principal, interest, escrow, fees and charges, and the amount, if any, sent to any suspense or unapplied funds account; and

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-3-ii
paragraph.content: The total of all payments received since the beginning of the current calendar year, including a breakdown of that total showing the amount, if any, that was applied to principal, interest, escrow, fees and charges, and the amount, if any, currently held in any suspense or unapplied funds account.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b
paragraph.title: Certain variable-rate transactions.
paragraph.content: Certain variable-rate transactions. Except as provided in paragraph (d) of this section, if the annual percentage rate may increase after consummation in a transaction secured by the consumer's principal dwelling with a term greater than one year, the following disclosures must be provided at the time an application form is provided or before the consumer pays a non-refundable fee, whichever is earlier (except that the disclosures may be delivered or placed in the mail not later than three business days following receipt of a consumer's application when the application reaches the creditor by telephone, or through an intermediary agent or broker):

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-1
paragraph.content: The booklet titled Consumer Handbook on Adjustable Rate Mortgages, or a suitable substitute.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2
paragraph.content: A loan program disclosure for each variable-rate program in which the consumer expresses an interest. The following disclosures, as applicable, shall be provided:

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-i
paragraph.content: The fact that the interest rate, payment, or term of the loan can change.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-ii
paragraph.content: The index or formula used in making adjustments, and a source of information about the index or formula.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-iii
paragraph.content: An explanation of how the interest rate and payment will be determined, including an explanation of how the index is adjusted, such as by the addition of a margin.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-iv
paragraph.content: A statement that the consumer should ask about the current margin value and current interest rate.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-v
paragraph.content: The fact that the interest rate will be discounted, and a statement that the consumer should ask about the amount of the interest rate discount.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-vi
paragraph.content: The frequency of interest rate and payment changes.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-vii
paragraph.content: Any rules relating to changes in the index, interest rate, payment amount, and outstanding loan balance including, for example, an explanation of interest rate or payment limitations, negative amortization, and interest rate carryover.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-viii
paragraph.content: At the option of the creditor, either of the following:

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-viii-A
paragraph.content: A historical example, based on a $10,000 loan amount, illustrating how payments and the loan balance would have been affected by interest rate changes implemented according to the terms of the loan program disclosure. The example shall reflect the most recent 15 years of index values. The example shall reflect all significant loan program terms, such as negative amortization, interest rate carryover, interest rate discounts, and interest rate and payment limitations, that would have been affected by the index movement during the period.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-viii-B
paragraph.content: The maximum interest rate and payment for a $10,000 loan originated at the initial interest rate (index value plus margin, adjusted by the amount of any discount or premium) in effect as of an identified month and year for the loan program disclosure assuming the maximum periodic increases in rates and payments under the program; and the initial interest rate and payment for that loan and a statement that the periodic payment may increase or decrease substantially depending on changes in the rate.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-ix
paragraph.content: An explanation of how the consumer may calculate the payments for the loan amount to be borrowed based on either:

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-ix-A
paragraph.content: The most recent payment shown in the historical example in paragraph (b)(2)(viii)(A) of this section; or

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-ix-B
paragraph.content: The initial interest rate used to calculate the maximum interest rate and payment in paragraph (b)(2)(viii)(B) of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-x
paragraph.content: The fact that the loan program contains a demand feature.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-xi
paragraph.content: The type of information that will be provided in notices of adjustments and the timing of such notices.

paragraph.label: 1026-19-b-2-xii
paragraph.content: A statement that disclosure forms are available for the creditor's other variable-rate loan programs.

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-1
paragraph.title: Amount due.
paragraph.content: Amount due. Grouped together in close proximity to each other and located at the top of the first page of the statement:

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-1-i
paragraph.content: The payment due date;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-1-ii
paragraph.content: The amount of any late payment fee, and the date on which that fee will be imposed if payment has not been received; and

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-1-iii
paragraph.content: The amount due, shown more prominently than other disclosures on the page and, if the transaction has multiple payment options, the amount due under each of the payment options.

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-6
paragraph.title: Contact information.
paragraph.content: Contact information. A toll-free telephone number and, if applicable, an electronic mailing address that may be used by the consumer to obtain information about the consumer's account, located on the front page of the statement.

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-7
paragraph.title: Account information.
paragraph.content: Account information. The following information:

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-7-i
paragraph.content: The amount of the outstanding principal balance;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-7-ii
paragraph.content: The current interest rate in effect for the mortgage loan;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-7-iii
paragraph.content: The date after which the interest rate may next change;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-7-iv
paragraph.content: The existence of any prepayment penalty, as defined in § 1026.32(b)(6)(i), that may be charged;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-7-v
paragraph.content: The Web site to access either the Bureau list or the HUD list of homeownership counselors and counseling organizations and the HUD toll-free telephone number to access contact information for homeownership counselors or counseling organizations; and

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-4
paragraph.title: Transaction activity.
paragraph.content: Transaction activity. A list of all the transaction activity that occurred since the last statement. For purposes of this paragraph (d)(4), transaction activity means any activity that causes a credit or debit to the amount currently due. This list must include the date of the transaction, a brief description of the transaction, and the amount of the transaction for each activity on the list.

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-5
paragraph.title: Partial payment information.
paragraph.content: Partial payment information. If a statement reflects a partial payment that was placed in a suspense or unapplied funds account, information explaining what must be done for the funds to be applied. The information must be on the front page of the statement or, alternatively, may be included on a separate page enclosed with the periodic statement or in a separate letter.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a
paragraph.title: Loan originator and mortgage broker defined
paragraph.content: Definitions.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1
paragraph.title: Loan originator.
paragraph.content: Loan originator.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1-i
paragraph.content: For purposes of this section, the term “loan originator” means a person who, in expectation of direct or indirect compensation or other monetary gain or for direct or indirect compensation or other monetary gain, performs any of the following activities: takes an application, offers, arranges, assists a consumer in obtaining or applying to obtain, negotiates, or otherwise obtains or makes an extension of consumer credit for another person; or through advertising or other means of communication represents to the public that such person can or will perform any of these activities. The term “loan originator” includes an employee, agent, or contractor of the creditor or loan originator organization if the employee, agent, or contractor meets this definition. The term “loan originator” includes a creditor that engages in loan origination activities if the creditor does not finance the transaction at consummation out of the creditor's own resources, including by drawing on a bona fide warehouse line of credit or out of deposits held by the creditor. All creditors that engage in any of the foregoing loan origination activities are loan originators for purposes of paragraphs (f) and (g) of this section. The term does not include:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1-i-A
paragraph.content: A person who does not take a consumer credit application or offer or negotiate credit terms available from a creditor, but who performs purely administrative or clerical tasks on behalf of a person who does engage in such activities.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1-i-B
paragraph.content: An employee of a manufactured home retailer who does not take a consumer credit application, offer or negotiate credit terms available from a creditor, or advise a consumer on credit terms (including rates, fees, and other costs) available from a creditor.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1-i-C
paragraph.content: A person that performs only real estate brokerage activities and is licensed or registered in accordance with applicable State law, unless such person is compensated by a creditor or loan originator or by any agent of such creditor or loan originator for a particular consumer credit transaction subject to this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1-i-D
paragraph.content: A seller financer that meets the criteria in paragraph (a)(4) or (a)(5) of this section, as applicable.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1-i-E
paragraph.content: A servicer or servicer's employees, agents, and contractors who offer or negotiate terms for purposes of renegotiating, modifying, replacing, or subordinating principal of existing mortgages where consumers are behind in their payments, in default, or have a reasonable likelihood of defaulting or falling behind. This exception does not apply, however, to a servicer or servicer's employees, agents, and contractors who offer or negotiate a transaction that constitutes a refinancing under § 1026.20(a) or obligates a different consumer on the existing debt.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1-ii
paragraph.content: An “individual loan originator” is a natural person who meets the definition of “loan originator” in paragraph (a)(1)(i) of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1-iii
paragraph.content: A “loan originator organization” is any loan originator, as defined in paragraph (a)(1)(i) of this section, that is not an individual loan originator.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-2
paragraph.title: Mortgage broker.
paragraph.content: Mortgage broker. For purposes of this section, a mortgage broker with respect to a particular transaction is any loan originator that is not an employee of the creditor.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-3
paragraph.title: Compensation.
paragraph.content: Compensation. The term “compensation” includes salaries, commissions, and any financial or similar incentive.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-4
paragraph.title: Seller financers; three properties.
paragraph.content: Seller financers; three properties. A person (as defined in § 1026.2(a)(22)) that meets all of the following criteria is not a loan originator under paragraph (a)(1) of this section:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-4-i
paragraph.content: The person provides seller financing for the sale of three or fewer properties in any 12-month period to purchasers of such properties, each of which is owned by the person and serves as security for the financing.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-4-ii
paragraph.content: The person has not constructed, or acted as a contractor for the construction of, a residence on the property in the ordinary course of business of the person.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-4-iii
paragraph.content: The person provides seller financing that meets the following requirements:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-4-iii-A
paragraph.content: The financing is fully amortizing.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-4-iii-B
paragraph.content: The financing is one that the person determines in good faith the consumer has a reasonable ability to repay.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-4-iii-C
paragraph.content: The financing has a fixed rate or an adjustable rate that is adjustable after five or more years, subject to reasonable annual and lifetime limitations on interest rate increases. If the financing agreement has an adjustable rate, the rate is determined by the addition of a margin to an index rate and is subject to reasonable rate adjustment limitations. The index the adjustable rate is based on is a widely available index such as indices for U.S. Treasury securities or LIBOR.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-5
paragraph.title: Seller financers; one property.
paragraph.content: Seller financers; one property. A natural person, estate, or trust that meets all of the following criteria is not a loan originator under paragraph (a)(1) of this section:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-5-i
paragraph.content: The natural person, estate, or trust provides seller financing for the sale of only one property in any 12-month period to purchasers of such property, which is owned by the natural person, estate, or trust and serves as security for the financing.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-5-ii
paragraph.content: The natural person, estate, or trust has not constructed, or acted as a contractor for the construction of, a residence on the property in the ordinary course of business of the person.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-5-iii
paragraph.content: The natural person, estate, or trust provides seller financing that meets the following requirements:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-5-iii-A
paragraph.content: The financing has a repayment schedule that does not result in negative amortization.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-5-iii-B
paragraph.content: The financing has a fixed rate or an adjustable rate that is adjustable after five or more years, subject to reasonable annual and lifetime limitations on interest rate increases. If the financing agreement has an adjustable rate, the rate is determined by the addition of a margin to an index rate and is subject to reasonable rate adjustment limitations. The index the adjustable rate is based on is a widely available index such as indices for U.S. Treasury securities or LIBOR.

paragraph.label: 1026-17-b
paragraph.title: Time of disclosures.
paragraph.content: Time of disclosures. The creditor shall make disclosures before consummation of the transaction. In certain residential mortgage transactions, special timing requirements are set forth in § 1026.19(a). In certain variable-rate transactions, special timing requirements for variable-rate disclosures are set forth in § 1026.19(b) and § 1026.20(c) and (d). For private education loan disclosures made in compliance with § 1026.47, special timing requirements are set forth in § 1026.46(d). In certain transactions involving mail or telephone orders or a series of sales, the timing of disclosures may be delayed in accordance with paragraphs (g) and (h) of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-b
paragraph.content: Scope. Paragraph (c) of this section applies to closed-end consumer credit transactions secured by a consumer's principal dwelling. Paragraphs (d), (e), (f), (g), (h), and (i) of this section apply to closed-end consumer credit transactions secured by a dwelling. This section does not apply to a home equity line of credit subject to § 1026.40, except that paragraphs (h) and (i) of this section apply to such credit when secured by the consumer's principal dwelling. Paragraphs (d), (e), (f), (g), (h), and (i) of this section do not apply to a loan that is secured by a consumer's interest in a timeshare plan described in 11 U.S.C. 101(53D).

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d
paragraph.title: Prohibited payments to loan originators
paragraph.content: Prohibited payments to loan originators —

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1
paragraph.title: Payments based on transaction terms or conditions.
paragraph.content: Payments based on a term of a transaction.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-i
paragraph.content: Except as provided in paragraph (d)(1)(iii) or (iv) of this section, in connection with a consumer credit transaction secured by a dwelling, no loan originator shall receive and no person shall pay to a loan originator, directly or indirectly, compensation in an amount that is based on a term of a transaction, the terms of multiple transactions by an individual loan originator, or the terms of multiple transactions by multiple individual loan originators. If a loan originator's compensation is based in whole or in part on a factor that is a proxy for a term of a transaction, the loan originator's compensation is based on a term of a transaction. A factor that is not itself a term of a transaction is a proxy for a term of the transaction if the factor consistently varies with that term over a significant number of transactions, and the loan originator has the ability, directly or indirectly, to add, drop, or change the factor in originating the transaction.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-ii
paragraph.content: For purposes of this paragraph (d)(1) only, a “term of a transaction” is any right or obligation of the parties to a credit transaction. The amount of credit extended is not a term of a transaction or a proxy for a term of a transaction, provided that compensation received by or paid to a loan originator, directly or indirectly, is based on a fixed percentage of the amount of credit extended; however, such compensation may be subject to a minimum or maximum dollar amount.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-iii
paragraph.content: An individual loan originatoroan originator may receive, and a person may pay to an individual loan originatordual loan originator, compensation in the form of a contribution to a defined contribution plan that is a designated tax-advantaged plan or a benefit under a defined benefit plan that is a designated tax-advantaged plan. In the case of a contribution to a defined contribution plan, the contribution shall not be directly or indirectly based on the terms of that individual loan originator's transactions. As used in this paragraph (d)(1)(iii), “designated tax-advantaged plan” means any plan that meets the requirements of Internal Revenue Code section 401(a), 26 U.S.C. 401(a); employee annuity plan described in Internal Revenue Code section 403(a), 26 U.S.C. 403(a); simple retirement account, as defined in Internal Revenue Code section 408(p), 26 U.S.C. 408(p); simplified employee pension described in Internal Revenue Code section 408(k), 26 U.S.C. 408(k); annuity contract described in Internal Revenue Code section 403(b), 26 U.S.C. 403(b); or eligible deferred compensation plan, as defined in Internal Revenue Code section 457(b), 26 U.S.C. 457(b).

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-iv
paragraph.content: An individual loan originator may receive, and a person may pay to an individual loan originator, compensation under a non-deferred profits-based compensation plan (i.e., any arrangement for the payment of non-deferred compensation that is determined with reference to the profits of the person from mortgage-related business), provided that:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-iv-A
paragraph.content: The compensation paid to an individual loan originator pursuant to this paragraph (d)(1)(iv) is not directly or indirectly based on the terms of that individual loan originator's transactions that are subject to this paragraph (d); and

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-iv-B
paragraph.content: At least one of the following conditions is satisfied:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-iv-B-1
paragraph.content: The compensation paid to an individual loan originator pursuant to this paragraph (d)(1)(iv) does not, in the aggregate, exceed 10 percent of the individual loan originator's total compensation corresponding to the time period for which the compensation under the non-deferred profits-based compensation plan is paid; or

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-iv-B-2
paragraph.content: The individual loan originator was a loan originator for ten or fewer transactions subject to this paragraph (d) consummated during the 12-month period preceding the date of the compensation determination.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2
paragraph.title: Payments by persons other than consumer.
paragraph.content: Payments by persons other than consumer.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2-i
paragraph.content: Dual compensation.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2-i-A
paragraph.content: Except as provided in paragraph (d)(2)(i)(C) of this section, if any loan originator receives compensation directly from a consumer in a consumer credit transaction secured by a dwelling:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2-i-A-1
paragraph.content: No loan originator shall receive compensation, directly or indirectly, from any person other than the consumer in connection with the transaction; and

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2-i-A-2
paragraph.content: No person who knows or has reason to know of the consumer-paid compensation to the loan originator (other than the consumer) shall pay any compensation to a loan originator, directly or indirectly, in connection with the transaction.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2-i-B
paragraph.content: Compensation received directly from a consumer includes payments to a loan originator made pursuant to an agreement between the consumer and a person other than the creditor or its affiliates, under which such other person agrees to provide funds toward the consumer's costs of the transaction (including loan originator compensation).

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2-i-C
paragraph.content: If a loan originator organization receives compensation directly from a consumer in connection with a transaction, the loan originator organization may pay compensation to an individual loan originator, and the individual loan originator may receive compensation from the loan originator organization, subject to paragraph (d)(1) of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2-ii
paragraph.content: Exemption. A payment to a loan originator that is otherwise prohibited by section 129B(c)(2)(A) of the Truth in Lending Act is nevertheless permitted pursuant to section 129B(c)(2)(B) of the Act, regardless of whether the consumer makes any upfront payment of discount points, origination points, or fees, as described in section 129B(c)(2)(B)(ii) of the Act, as long as the loan originator does not receive any compensation directly from the consumer as described in section 129B(c)(2)(B)(i) of the Act.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-3
paragraph.title: Affiliates.
paragraph.content: Affiliates. For purposes of this paragraph (d), affiliates shall be treated as a single “person.”

paragraph.label: 1026-H-4(C)-p32

paragraph.label: 1026-H-4(C)-p33

paragraph.label: 1026-H-4(C)-p34

paragraph.label: 1026-H-4(C)-p35

paragraph.label: 1026-H-4(C)-p36

paragraph.label: 1026-H-4(C)-p37

paragraph.label: 1026-H-9-h6-p75
paragraph.content: You are entering into a new transaction to increase the amount of credit previously provided to you. Your home is the security for this new transaction. You have a legal right under Federal law to cancel this new transaction, without cost, within three business days from whichever of the following events occurs last:

paragraph.label: 1026-H-9-h6-p75-1
paragraph.content: the date of this new transaction, which is ______; or

paragraph.label: 1026-H-9-h6-p75-2
paragraph.content: the date you received your new Truth in Lending disclosures; or

paragraph.label: 1026-H-9-h6-p75-3
paragraph.content: the date you received this notice of your right to cancel.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-9-h6-p75-p76
paragraph.content: If you cancel this new transaction, it will not affect any amount that you presently owe. Your home is the security for that amount. Within 20 calendar days after we receive your notice of cancellation of this new transaction, we must take the steps necessary to reflect the fact that your home does not secure the increase of credit. We must also return any money you have given to us or anyone else in connection with this new transaction.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-9-h6-p75-p77
paragraph.content: You may keep any money we have given you in this new transaction until we have done the things mentioned above, but you must then offer to return the money at the address below.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-9-h6-p75-p78
paragraph.content: If we do not take possession of the money within 20 calendar days of your offer, you may keep it without further obligation.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-9-h7-p79
paragraph.content: If you decide to cancel this new transaction, you may do so by notifying us in writing, at

paragraph.label: 1026-H-9-h7-p81
paragraph.content: (Creditor's name and business address).

paragraph.label: 1026-H-9-h7-p82
paragraph.content: You may use any written statement that is signed and dated by you and states your intention to cancel, or you may use this notice by dating and signing below. Keep one copy of this notice because it contains important information about your rights.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-9-h7-p83
paragraph.content: If you cancel by mail or telegram, you must send the notice no later than midnight of

paragraph.label: 1026-H-9-h7-p86
paragraph.content: (or midnight of the third business day following the latest of the three events listed above).

paragraph.label: 1026-H-9-h7-p87
paragraph.content: If you send or deliver your written notice to cancel some other way, it must be delivered to the above address no later than that time.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-p94
paragraph.content: This disclosure describes the features of the adjustable-rate mortgage (ARM) program you are considering. Information on other ARM programs is available upon request.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-h9
paragraph.title: How Your Interest Rate and Payment Are Determined

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-h9-p95
paragraph.content: • Your interest rate will be based on an index rate plus a margin.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-h9-p96
paragraph.content: • Your payment will be based on the interest rate, loan balance, and loan term.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-h9-p97
paragraph.content: —The interest rate will be based on the weekly average yield on United States Treasury securities adjusted to a constant maturity of 1 year (your index), plus our margin. Ask us for our current interest rate and margin.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-h9-p98
paragraph.content: —Information about the index rate is published weekly in the Wall Street Journal.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-h9-p99
paragraph.content: • Your interest rate will equal the index rate plus our margin unless your interest rate “caps” limit the amount of change in the interest rate.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-h10
paragraph.title: How Your Interest Rate Can Change

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-h10-p100
paragraph.content: • Your interest rate can change yearly.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-h10-p101
paragraph.content: • Your interest rate cannot increase or decrease more than 2 percentage points per year.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-h10-p102
paragraph.content: • Your interest rate cannot increase or decrease more than 5 percentage points over the term of the loan.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-h11
paragraph.title: How Your Monthly Payment Can Change

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-h11-p103
paragraph.content: • Your monthly payment can increase or decrease substantially based on annual changes in the interest rate.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-h11-p104
paragraph.content: • [For example, on a $10,000, 30-year loan with an initial interest rate of 12.41 percent in effect in July 1996, the maximum amount that the interest rate can rise under this program is 5 percentage points, to 17.41 percent, and the monthly payment can rise from a first-year payment of $106.03 to a maximum of $145.34 in the fourth year. To see what your payment is, divide your mortgage amount by $10,000; then multiply the monthly payment by that amount. (For example, the monthly payment for a mortgage amount of $60,000 would be: $60,000 ÷ $10,000 = 6; 6 × 106.03 = $636.18 per month.)

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-h11-p105
paragraph.content: • You will be notified in writing 25 days before the annual payment adjustment may be made. This notice will contain information about your interest rates, payment amount and loan balance.]

paragraph.label: 1026-43-a-3-v-B
paragraph.content: A creditor designated as a Downpayment Assistance through Secondary Financing Provider, pursuant to 24 CFR 200.194(a), operating in accordance with regulations prescribed by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development applicable to such persons;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-a-3-v-C
paragraph.content: A creditor designated as a Community Housing Development Organization provided that the creditor has entered into a commitment with a participating jurisdiction and is undertaking a project under the HOME program, pursuant to the provisions of 24 CFR 92.300(a), and as the terms community housing development organization, commitment, participating jurisdiction, and project are defined under 24 CFR 92.2; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-a-3-v-D
paragraph.content: A creditor with a tax exemption ruling or determination letter from the Internal Revenue Service under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 (26 U.S.C. 501(c)(3); 26 CFR 1.501(c)(3)-1), provided that:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-a-3-v-D-1

paragraph.label: 1026-43-a-3-v-D-2
paragraph.content: During the calendar year preceding receipt of the consumer's application, the creditor extended credit secured by a dwelling only to consumers with income that did not exceed the low- and moderate-income household limit as established pursuant to section 102 of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974 (42 U.S.C. 5302(a)(20)) and amended from time to time by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, pursuant to 24 CFR 570.3;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-a-3-v-D-3

paragraph.label: 1026-43-a-3-v-D-4
paragraph.content: The creditor determines, in accordance with written procedures, that the consumer has a reasonable ability to repay the extension of credit.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-i
paragraph.title: Prohibition on financing single-premium credit insurance.
paragraph.content: Prohibition on financing single-premium credit insurance.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-i-1
paragraph.content: A creditor may not finance, directly or indirectly, any premiums or fees for credit insurance in connection with a consumer credit transaction secured by a dwelling (including a home equity line of credit secured by the consumer's principal dwelling). This prohibition does not apply to credit insurance for which premiums or fees are calculated and paid in full on a monthly basis.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-i-2
paragraph.content: For purposes of this paragraph (i), “credit insurance”:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-i-2-i
paragraph.content: Means credit life, credit disability, credit unemployment, or credit property insurance, or any other accident, loss-of-income, life, or health insurance, or any payments directly or indirectly for any debt cancellation or suspension agreement or contract, but

paragraph.label: 1026-36-i-2-ii
paragraph.content: Excludes credit unemployment insurance for which the unemployment insurance premiums are reasonable, the creditor receives no direct or indirect compensation in connection with the unemployment insurance premiums, and the unemployment insurance premiums are paid pursuant to a separate insurance contract and are not paid to an affiliate of the creditor.

appendixSection.label: 1026-G-1
appendixSection.subject: G-1—Balance Computation Methods Model Clauses (Home-Equity Plans)

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1-a
paragraph.content: Adjusted Balance Method

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1-p1
paragraph.content: We figure [a portion of] the finance charge on your account by applying the periodic rate to the “adjusted balance” of your account. We get the “adjusted balance” by taking the balance you owed at the end of the previous billing cycle and subtracting [any unpaid finance charges and] any payments and credits received during the present billing cycle.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1-b
paragraph.content: Previous Balance Method

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1-p2
paragraph.content: We figure [a portion of] the finance charge on your account by applying the periodic rate to the amount you owe at the beginning of each billing cycle [minus any unpaid finance charges]. We do not subtract any payments or credits received during the billing cycle. [The amount of payments and credits to your account this billing cycle was $ ____.]

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1-c
paragraph.content: Average Daily Balance Method (Excluding Current Transactions)

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1-p3
paragraph.content: We figure [a portion of] the finance charge on your account by applying the periodic rate to the “average daily balance” of your account (excluding current transactions). To get the “average daily balance” we take the beginning balance of your account each day and subtract any payments or credits [and any unpaid finance charges]. We do not add in any new [purchases/advances/loans]. This gives us the daily balance. Then, we add all the daily balances for the billing cycle together and divide the total by the number of days in the billing cycle. This gives us the “average daily balance.”

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1-d
paragraph.content: Average Daily Balance Method (Including Current Transactions)

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1-p4
paragraph.content: We figure [a portion of] the finance charge on your account by applying the periodic rate to the “average daily balance” of your account (including current transactions). To get the “average daily balance” we take the beginning balance of your account each day, add any new [purchases/advances/loans], and subtract any payments or credits, [and unpaid finance charges]. This gives us the daily balance. Then, we add up all the daily balances for the billing cycle and divide the total by the number of days in the billing cycle. This gives us the “average daily balance.”

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1-e
paragraph.content: Ending Balance Method

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1-p5
paragraph.content: We figure [a portion of] the finance charge on your account by applying the periodic rate to the amount you owe at the end of each billing cycle (including new purchases and deducting payments and credits made during the billing cycle).

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1-f
paragraph.content: Daily Balance Method (Including Current Transactions)

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1-p6
paragraph.content: We figure [a portion of] the finance charge on your account by applying the periodic rate to the “daily balance” of your account for each day in the billing cycle. To get the “daily balance” we take the beginning balance of your account each day, add any new [purchases/advances/fees], and subtract [any unpaid finance charges and] any payments or credits. This gives us the daily balance.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h2
paragraph.title: KEEP THIS NOTICE FOR FUTURE USE

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h2-p18
paragraph.content: This notice contains important information about your rights and our responsibilities under the Fair Credit Billing Act.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h3
paragraph.title: Notify Us in Case of Errors or Questions About Your Bill

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h3-p19
paragraph.content: If you think your bill is wrong, or if you need more information about a transaction on your bill, write us [on a separate sheet] at [address] [the address listed on your bill]. Write to us as soon as possible. We must hear from you no later than 60 days after we sent you the first bill on which the error or problem appeared. [You may also contact us on the Web: [Creditor Web or email address]] You can telephone us, but doing so will not preserve your rights.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h3-p20
paragraph.content: In your letter, give us the following information:

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h3-p21
paragraph.content: • Your name and account number.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h3-p22
paragraph.content: • The dollar amount of the suspected error.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h3-p23
paragraph.content: • Describe the error and explain, if you can, why you believe there is an error. If you need more information, describe the item you are not sure about.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h3-p24
paragraph.content: If you have authorized us to pay your credit card bill automatically from your savings or checking account, you can stop the payment on any amount you think is wrong. To stop the payment your letter must reach us three business days before the automatic payment is scheduled to occur.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h4
paragraph.title: Your Rights and Our Responsibilities After We Receive Your Written Notice

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h4-p25
paragraph.content: We must acknowledge your letter within 30 days, unless we have corrected the error by then. Within 90 days, we must either correct the error or explain why we believe the bill was correct.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h4-p26
paragraph.content: After we receive your letter, we cannot try to collect any amount you question, or report you as delinquent. We can continue to bill you for the amount you question, including finance charges, and we can apply any unpaid amount against your credit limit. You do not have to pay any questioned amount while we are investigating, but you are still obligated to pay the parts of your bill that are not in question.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h4-p27
paragraph.content: If we find that we made a mistake on your bill, you will not have to pay any finance charges related to any questioned amount. If we didn't make a mistake, you may have to pay finance charges, and you will have to make up any missed payments on the questioned amount. In either case, we will send you a statement of the amount you owe and the date that it is due.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h4-p28
paragraph.content: If you fail to pay the amount that we think you owe, we may report you as delinquent. However, if our explanation does not satisfy you and you write to us within ten days telling us that you still refuse to pay, we must tell anyone we report you to that you have a question about your bill. And, we must tell you the name of anyone we reported you to. We must tell anyone we report you to that the matter has been settled between us when it finally is.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h4-p29
paragraph.content: If we don't follow these rules, we can't collect the first $50 of the questioned amount, even if your bill was correct.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h5
paragraph.title: Special Rule for Credit Card Purchases

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h5-p30
paragraph.content: If you have a problem with the quality of property or services that you purchased with a credit card, and you have tried in good faith to correct the problem with the merchant, you may have the right not to pay the remaining amount due on the property or services.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h5-p31
paragraph.content: There are two limitations on this right:

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h5-p31-a
paragraph.content: You must have made the purchase in your home state or, if not within your home state within 100 miles of your current mailing address; and

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h5-p31-b
paragraph.content: The purchase price must have been more than $50.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h5-p31-p32
paragraph.content: These limitations do not apply if we own or operate the merchant, or if we mailed you the advertisement for the property or services.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h6
paragraph.title: Your Billing Rights: Keep This Document For Future Use

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h6-p33
paragraph.content: This notice tells you about your rights and our responsibilities under the Fair Credit Billing Act.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h7
paragraph.title: What To Do If You Find A Mistake On Your Statement

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h7-p34
paragraph.content: If you think there is an error on your statement, write to us at:

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h7-p35
paragraph.content: [Creditor Name]

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h7-p36
paragraph.content: [Creditor Address]

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h7-p37
paragraph.content: [You may also contact us on the Web: [Creditor Web or email address]]

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h7-p38
paragraph.content: In your letter, give us the following information:

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h7-p39
paragraph.content: • Account information: Your name and account number.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h7-p40
paragraph.content: • Dollar amount: The dollar amount of the suspected error.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h7-p41
paragraph.content: • Description of problem: If you think there is an error on your bill, describe what you believe is wrong and why you believe it is a mistake.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h7-p42
paragraph.content: You must contact us:

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h7-p43
paragraph.content: • Within 60 days after the error appeared on your statement.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h7-p44
paragraph.content: • At least 3 business days before an automated payment is scheduled, if you want to stop payment on the amount you think is wrong.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h7-p45
paragraph.content: You must notify us of any potential errors in writing [or electronically]. You may call us, but if you do we are not required to investigate any potential errors and you may have to pay the amount in question.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h8
paragraph.title: What Will Happen After We Receive Your Letter

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h8-p46
paragraph.content: When we receive your letter, we must do two things:

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h8-p46-1
paragraph.content: Within 30 days of receiving your letter, we must tell you that we received your letter. We will also tell you if we have already corrected the error.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h8-p46-2
paragraph.content: Within 90 days of receiving your letter, we must either correct the error or explain to you why we believe the bill is correct.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h8-p46-p47
paragraph.content: While we investigate whether or not there has been an error:

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h8-p46-p48
paragraph.content: • We cannot try to collect the amount in question, or report you as delinquent on that amount.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h8-p46-p49
paragraph.content: • The charge in question may remain on your statement, and we may continue to charge you interest on that amount.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h8-p46-p50
paragraph.content: • While you do not have to pay the amount in question, you are responsible for the remainder of your balance.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h8-p46-p51
paragraph.content: • We can apply any unpaid amount against your credit limit.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h8-p46-p52
paragraph.content: After we finish our investigation, one of two things will happen:

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h8-p46-p53
paragraph.content: • If we made a mistake: You will not have to pay the amount in question or any interest or other fees related to that amount.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h8-p46-p54
paragraph.content: • If we do not believe there was a mistake: You will have to pay the amount in question, along with applicable interest and fees. We will send you a statement of the amount you owe and the date payment is due. We may then report you as delinquent if you do not pay the amount we think you owe.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h8-p46-p55
paragraph.content: If you receive our explanation but still believe your bill is wrong, you must write to us within 10 days telling us that you still refuse to pay. If you do so, we cannot report you as delinquent without also reporting that you are questioning your bill. We must tell you the name of anyone to whom we reported you as delinquent, and we must let those organizations know when the matter has been settled between us.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h8-p46-p56
paragraph.content: If we do not follow all of the rules above, you do not have to pay the first $50 of the amount you question even if your bill is correct.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h9
paragraph.title: Your Rights If You Are Dissatisfied With Your Credit Card Purchases

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h9-p57
paragraph.content: If you are dissatisfied with the goods or services that you have purchased with your credit card, and you have tried in good faith to correct the problem with the merchant, you may have the right not to pay the remaining amount due on the purchase.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h9-p58
paragraph.content: To use this right, all of the following must be true:

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h9-p58-1
paragraph.content: The purchase must have been made in your home state or within 100 miles of your current mailing address, and the purchase price must have been more than $50. (Note: Neither of these are necessary if your purchase was based on an advertisement we mailed to you, or if we own the company that sold you the goods or services.)

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h9-p58-2
paragraph.content: You must have used your credit card for the purchase. Purchases made with cash advances from an ATM or with a check that accesses your credit card account do not qualify.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h9-p58-3
paragraph.content: You must not yet have fully paid for the purchase.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h9-p58-p59
paragraph.content: If all of the criteria above are met and you are still dissatisfied with the purchase, contact us in writing [or electronically] at:

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h9-p58-p60
paragraph.content: [Creditor Name]

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h9-p58-p61
paragraph.content: [Creditor Address]

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h9-p58-p62
paragraph.content: [[Creditor Web or email address]]

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h9-p58-p63
paragraph.content: While we investigate, the same rules apply to the disputed amount as discussed above. After we finish our investigation, we will tell you our decision. At that point, if we think you owe an amount and you do not pay, we may report you as delinquent.

[You may also contact us on the Web: [Creditor Web or email address].] We must hear from you no later than 60 days after we sent you the first bill on which the error or problem appeared. You can telephone us, but doing so will not preserve your rights.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-4-h10-h11-p67
paragraph.content: • The dollar amount of the suspected error.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-4-h10-h11-p68
paragraph.content: • Describe the error and explain, if you can, why you believe there is an error. If you need more information, describe the item you are unsure about.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-4-h10-h11-p69
paragraph.content: You do not have to pay any amount in question while we are investigating, but you are still obligated to pay the parts of your bill that are not in question. While we investigate your question, we cannot report you as delinquent or take any action to collect the amount you question.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-4-h10-h12
paragraph.title: Special Rule for Credit Card Purchases

paragraph.label: 1026-G-4-h10-h12-p70
paragraph.content: If you have a problem with the quality of goods or services that you purchased with a credit card, and you have tried in good faith to correct the problem with the merchant, you may not have to pay the remaining amount due on the goods or services. You have this protection only when the purchase price was more than $50 and the purchase was made in your home state or within 100 miles of your mailing address. (If we own or operate the merchant, or if we mailed you the advertisement for the property or services, all purchases are covered regardless of amount or location of purchase.)

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-iii
paragraph.content: The creditor considers at or before consummation the consumer's monthly debt-to-income ratio or residual income and verifies the debt obligations and income used to determine that ratio in accordance with paragraph (c)(7) of this section, except that the calculation of the payment on the covered transaction for purposes of determining the consumer's total monthly debt obligations in (c)(7)(i)(A) shall be determined in accordance with paragraph (f)(iv)(A) of this section, together with the consumer's monthly payments for all mortgage-related obligations and excluding the balloon payment;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-ii
paragraph.content: The creditor determines at or before consummation that the consumer can make all of the scheduled payments under the terms of the legal obligation, as described in paragraph (f)(1)(iv) of this section, together with the consumer's monthly payments for all mortgage-related obligations and excluding the balloon payment, from the consumer's current or reasonably expected income or assets other than the dwelling that secures the loan;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-2-i
paragraph.content: The creditor for the standard mortgage is the current holder of the existing non-standard mortgage or the servicer acting on behalf of the current holder;

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iv-A
paragraph.content: A county is “rural” during a calendar year if it is neither in a metropolitan statistical area nor in a micropolitan statistical area that is adjacent to a metropolitan statistical area, as those terms are defined by the U.S. Office of Management and Budget and as they are applied under currently applicable Urban Influence Codes (UICs), established by the United States Department of Agriculture's Economic Research Service (USDA-ERS). A creditor may rely as a safe harbor on the list of counties published by the Bureau to determine whether a county qualifies as “rural” for a particular calendar year.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-iv-B-2
paragraph.content: The individual loan originator was a loan originator for ten or fewer transactions subject to this paragraph (d) consummated during the 12-month period preceding the date of the compensation determination.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-1-i
paragraph.title: In general.
paragraph.content: In general. For purposes of this paragraph (d), an adjustable-rate mortgage or “ARM” is a closed-end consumer credit transaction secured by the consumer's principal dwelling in which the annual percentage rate may increase after consummation.

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-iv
paragraph.content: Premiums or other charges payable at or before consummation for any credit life, credit disability, credit unemployment, or credit property insurance, or any other life, accident, health, or loss-of-income insurance for which the creditor is a beneficiary, or any payments directly or indirectly for any debt cancellation or suspension agreement or contract;

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-iv-B-1
paragraph.content: The compensation paid to an individual loan originator pursuant to this paragraph (d)(1)(iv) does not, in the aggregate, exceed 10 percent of the individual loan originator's total compensation corresponding to the time period for which the compensation under the non-deferred profits-based compensation plan is paid; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-2
paragraph.title: Limits on prepayment penalties.
paragraph.content: Limits on prepayment penalties. A prepayment penalty:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-2-i
paragraph.content: Must not apply after the three-year period following consummation; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-2-ii
paragraph.content: Must not exceed the following percentages of the amount of the outstanding loan balance prepaid:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-2-ii-A
paragraph.content: 2 percent, if incurred during the first two years following consummation; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-2-ii-B
paragraph.content: 1 percent, if incurred during the third year following consummation.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-2-viii
paragraph.content: The consumer's credit history.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-ii
paragraph.content: A table containing the following information:

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-ii-A
paragraph.content: The current and new interest rates;

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-ii-B
paragraph.content: The current and new payments and the date the first new payment is due; and

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-ii-C
paragraph.content: For interest-only or negatively-amortizing payments, the amount of the current and new payment allocated to principal, interest, and taxes and insurance in escrow, as applicable. The current payment allocation disclosed shall be the payment allocation for the last payment prior to the date of the disclosure. The new payment allocation disclosed shall be the expected payment allocation for the first payment for which the new interest rate will apply.

appendix.label: 1026-Q
appendix.appendixTitle: Appendix Q to Part 1026—Standards for Determining Monthly Debt and Income

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A
paragraph.content: Stability of Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-1
paragraph.title: Effective Income.
paragraph.content: Effective Income. Income may not be used in calculating the consumer's income ratios if it comes from any source that cannot be verified, is not stable, or will not continue.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-2
paragraph.title: Verifying Employment History.
paragraph.content: Verifying Employment History.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-2-a
paragraph.content: The creditor must verify the consumer's employment for the most recent two full years, and the consumer must:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-2-a-i
paragraph.content: Explain any gaps in employment that span one or more months, and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-2-a-ii
paragraph.content: Indicate if he/she was in school or the military for the recent two full years, providing evidence supporting this claim, such as college transcripts, or discharge papers.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-2-b
paragraph.content: Allowances can be made for seasonal employment, typical for the building trades and agriculture, if documented by the creditor.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-2-p2
paragraph.content: ```note Note: A consumer with a 25 percent or greater ownership interest in a business is considered self-employed and will be evaluated as a self-employed consumer for underwriting purposes. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-3
paragraph.title: Analyzing a Consumer's Employment Record.
paragraph.content: Analyzing a Consumer's Employment Record.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-3-a
paragraph.content: When analyzing the probability of continued employment, creditors must examine:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-3-a-i
paragraph.content: The consumer's past employment record;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-3-a-ii
paragraph.content: Qualifications for the position;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-3-a-iii
paragraph.content: Previous training and education; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-3-a-iv
paragraph.content: The employer's confirmation of continued employment.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-3-b
paragraph.content: Favorably consider a consumer for a mortgage if he/she changes jobs frequently within the same line of work, but continues to advance in income or benefits. In this analysis, income stability takes precedence over job stability.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-4
paragraph.title: Consumers Returning to Work After an Extended Absence.
paragraph.content: Consumers Returning to Work After an Extended Absence. A consumer's income may be considered effective and stable when recently returning to work after an extended absence if he/she:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-4-a
paragraph.content: Is employed in the current job for six months or longer; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-4-b
paragraph.content: Can document a two-year work history prior to an absence from employment using:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-4-b-i
paragraph.content: Traditional employment verifications; and/or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-4-b-ii
paragraph.content: Copies of IRS Form W-2s or pay stubs.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-4-b-p3
paragraph.content: ```note Note: An acceptable employment situation includes individuals who took several years off from employment to raise children, then returned to the workforce. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-4-c
paragraph.content: Important: Situations not meeting the criteria listed above may not be used in qualifying. Extended absence is defined as six months.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B
paragraph.content: Salary, Wage and Other Forms of Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-1
paragraph.title: General Policy on Consumer Income Analysis.
paragraph.content: General Policy on Consumer Income Analysis.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-1-a
paragraph.content: The income of each consumer who will be obligated for the mortgage debt must be analyzed to determine whether his/her income level can be reasonably expected to continue through at least the first three years of the mortgage loan.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-1-b
paragraph.content: In most cases, a consumer's income is limited to salaries or wages. Income from other sources can be considered as effective, when properly verified and documented by the creditor.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-1-p4
paragraph.content: ```note Notes: i. Effective income for consumers planning to retire during the first three-year period must include the amount of: a. Documented retirement benefits; b. Social Security payments; or c. Other payments expected to be received in retirement. ii. Creditors must not ask the consumer about possible, future maternity leave. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-2
paragraph.title: Overtime and Bonus Income.
paragraph.content: Overtime and Bonus Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-2-a
paragraph.content: Overtime and bonus income can be used to qualify the consumer if he/she has received this income for the past two years, and it will likely continue. If the employment verification states that the overtime and bonus income is unlikely to continue, it may not be used in qualifying.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-2-b
paragraph.content: The creditor must develop an average of bonus or overtime income for the past two years. Periods of overtime and bonus income less than two years may be acceptable, provided the creditor can justify and document in writing the reason for using the income for qualifying purposes.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-3
paragraph.title: Establishing an Overtime and Bonus Income Earning Trend.
paragraph.content: Establishing an Overtime and Bonus Income Earning Trend.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-3-a
paragraph.content: The creditor must establish and document an earnings trend for overtime and bonus income. If either type of income shows a continual decline, the creditor must document in writing a sound rationalization for including the income when qualifying the consumer.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-3-b
paragraph.content: A period of more than two years must be used in calculating the average overtime and bonus income if the income varies significantly from year to year.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-4
paragraph.title: Qualifying Part-Time Income.
paragraph.content: Qualifying Part-Time Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-4-a
paragraph.content: Part-time and seasonal income can be used to qualify the consumer if the creditor documents that the consumer has worked the part-time job uninterrupted for the past two years, and plans to continue. Many low and moderate income families rely on part-time and seasonal income for day to day needs, and creditors should not restrict consideration of such income when qualifying these consumers.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-4-b
paragraph.content: Part-time income received for less than two years may be included as effective income, provided that the creditor justifies and documents that the income is likely to continue.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-4-c
paragraph.content: Part-time income not meeting the qualifying requirements may not be used in qualifying.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-4-p5
paragraph.content: ```note Note: For qualifying purposes, “part-time” income refers to employment taken to supplement the consumer's income from regular employment; part-time employment is not a primary job and it is worked less than 40 hours. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-5
paragraph.title: Income from Seasonal Employment.
paragraph.content: Income from Seasonal Employment.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-5-a
paragraph.content: Seasonal income is considered uninterrupted, and may be used to qualify the consumer, if the creditor documents that the consumer:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-5-a-i
paragraph.content: Has worked the same job for the past two years, and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-5-a-ii
paragraph.content: Expects to be rehired the next season.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-5-b
paragraph.content: Seasonal employment includes:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-5-b-i
paragraph.content: Umpiring baseball games in the summer; or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-5-b-ii
paragraph.content: Working at a department store during the holiday shopping season.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-6
paragraph.title: Primary Employment Less Than 40 Hour Work Week.
paragraph.content: Primary Employment Less Than 40 Hour Work Week.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-6-a
paragraph.content: When a consumer's primary employment is less than a typical 40-hour work week, the creditor should evaluate the stability of that income as regular, on-going primary employment.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-6-b
paragraph.content: Example: A registered nurse may have worked 24 hours per week for the last year. Although this job is less than the 40-hour work week, it is the consumer's primary employment, and should be considered effective income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-7
paragraph.title: Commission Income.
paragraph.content: Commission Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-7-a
paragraph.content: Commission income must be averaged over the previous two years. To qualify commission income, the consumer must provide:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-7-a-i
paragraph.content: Copies of signed tax returns for the last two years; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-7-a-ii
paragraph.content: The most recent pay stub.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-7-b
paragraph.content: Consumers whose commission income was received for more than one year, but less than two years may be considered favorably if the underwriter can:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-7-b-i
paragraph.content: Document the likelihood that the income will continue, and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-7-b-ii
paragraph.content: Soundly rationalize accepting the commission income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-7-b-p6
paragraph.content: ```note Notes: i. Unreimbursed business expenses must be subtracted from gross income. ii. A commissioned consumer is one who receives more than 25 percent of his/her annual income from commissions. iii. A tax transcript obtained directly from the IRS may be used in lieu of signed tax returns, and the cost of the transcript may be charged to the consumer. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-8
paragraph.title: Qualifying Commission Income Earned for Less Than One Year.
paragraph.content: Qualifying Commission Income Earned for Less Than One Year.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-8-a
paragraph.content: Commission income earned for less than one year is not considered effective income. Exceptions may be made for situations in which the consumer's compensation was changed from salary to commission within a similar position with the same employer.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-8-b
paragraph.content: A consumer may also qualify when the portion of earnings not attributed to commissions would be sufficient to qualify the consumer for the mortgage.
