paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-9
paragraph.title: Employer Differential Payments.
paragraph.content: Employer Differential Payments. If the employer subsidizes a consumer's mortgage payment through direct payments, the amount of the payments:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-9-a
paragraph.content: Is considered gross income, and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-9-b
paragraph.content: Cannot be used to offset the mortgage payment directly, even if the employer pays the servicing creditor directly.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-10
paragraph.title: Retirement Income.
paragraph.content: Retirement Income. Retirement income must be verified from the former employer, or from Federal tax returns. If any retirement income, such as employer pensions or 401(k)'s, will cease within the first full three years of the mortgage loan, such income may not be used in qualifying.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-11
paragraph.title: Social Security Income.
paragraph.content: Social Security Income. Social Security income must be verified by the Social Security Administration or on Federal tax returns. If any benefits expire within the first full three years of the loan, the income source may not be used in qualifying.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12
paragraph.title: Automobile Allowances and Expense Account Payments.
paragraph.content: Automobile Allowances and Expense Account Payments.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-a
paragraph.content: Only the amount by which the consumer's automobile allowance or expense account payments exceed actual expenditures may be considered income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-b
paragraph.content: To establish the amount to add to gross income, the consumer must provide the following:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-b-i
paragraph.content: IRS Form 2106, Employee Business Expenses, for the previous two years; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-b-ii
paragraph.content: Employer verification that the payments will continue.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-c
paragraph.content: If the consumer uses the standard per-mile rate in calculating automobile expenses, as opposed to the actual cost method, the portion that the IRS considers depreciation may be added back to income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-d
paragraph.content: Expenses that must be treated as recurring debt include:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-d-i
paragraph.content: The consumer's monthly car payment; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-d-ii
paragraph.content: Any loss resulting from the calculation of the difference between the actual expenditures and the expense account allowance.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-p7
paragraph.content: ```note Notes: i. The creditor must obtain a complete copy of the current awards letter. ii. Not all Social Security income is for retirement-aged recipients; therefore, documented continuation is required. iii. Some portion of Social Security income may be “grossed up” if deemed nontaxable by the IRS. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-C
paragraph.content: Consumers Employed by a Family Owned Business.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-C-1
paragraph.title: Income Documentation Requirement.
paragraph.content: Income Documentation Requirement.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-C-p8
paragraph.content: In addition to normal employment verification, a consumer employed by a family owned business is required to provide evidence that he/she is not an owner of the business, which may include:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-C-p8-a
paragraph.content: Copies of signed personal tax returns, or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-C-p8-b
paragraph.content: A signed copy of the corporate tax return showing ownership percentage.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-C-p8-p9
paragraph.content: ```note Note:A tax transcript obtained directly from the IRS may be used in lieu of signed tax returns, and the cost of the transcript may be charged to the consumer. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D
paragraph.content: General Information on Self-Employed Consumers and Income Analysis.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-1
paragraph.title: Definition: Self Employed Consumer.
paragraph.content: Definition: Self Employed Consumer. A consumer with a 25 percent or greater ownership interest in a business is considered self-employed.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-2
paragraph.title: Types of Business Structures.
paragraph.content: Types of Business Structures. There are four basic types of business structures. They include:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-2-a
paragraph.content: Sole proprietorships;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-2-b
paragraph.content: Corporations;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-2-c
paragraph.content: Limited liability or “S” corporations; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-2-d
paragraph.content: Partnerships.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-3
paragraph.title: Minimum Length of Self Employment.
paragraph.content: Minimum Length of Self Employment.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-3-a
paragraph.content: Income from self-employment is considered stable, and effective, if the consumer has been self-employed for two or more years.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-3-b
paragraph.content: Due to the high probability of failure during the first few years of a business, the requirements described in the table below are necessary for consumers who have been self-employed for less than two years.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-4
paragraph.title: General Documentation Requirements for Self Employed Consumers.
paragraph.content: General Documentation Requirements for Self Employed Consumers. Self-employed consumers must provide the following documentation:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-4-a
paragraph.content: Signed, dated individual tax returns, with all applicable tax schedules for the most recent two years;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-4-b
paragraph.content: For a corporation, “S” corporation, or partnership, signed copies of Federal business income tax returns for the last two years, with all applicable tax schedules;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-4-c
paragraph.content: MISSING CONTENT

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-4-d
paragraph.content: Business credit report for corporations and “S” corporations.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-5
paragraph.title: Establishing a Consumer's Earnings Trend.
paragraph.content: Establishing a Consumer's Earnings Trend.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-5-a
paragraph.content: When qualifying a consumer for a mortgage loan, the creditor must establish the consumer's earnings trend from the previous two years using the consumer's tax returns.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-5-b
paragraph.content: If a consumer:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-5-b-i
paragraph.content: Provides quarterly tax returns, the income analysis may include income through the period covered by the tax filings, or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-5-b-ii
paragraph.content: MISSING CONTENT

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-5-c
paragraph.content: MISSING CONTENT

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-5-d
paragraph.content: MISSING CONTENT

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-6
paragraph.title: Analyzing the Business's Financial Strength:
paragraph.content: Analyzing the Business's Financial Strength:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-6-a
paragraph.content: To determine if the business is expected to generate sufficient income for the consumer's needs, the creditor must carefully analyze the business's financial strength, including the:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-6-a-i
paragraph.content: Source of the business's income;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-6-a-ii
paragraph.content: General economic outlook for similar businesses in the area.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-6-b
paragraph.content: Annual earnings that are stable or increasing are acceptable, while businesses that show a significant decline in income over the analysis period are not acceptable.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-E
paragraph.content: Income Analysis: Individual Tax Returns (IRS Form 1040).

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-E-1
paragraph.title: General Policy on Adjusting Income Based on a Review of IRS Form 1040.
paragraph.content: General Policy on Adjusting Income Based on a Review of IRS Form 1040. The amount shown on a consumer's IRS Form 1040 as adjusted gross income must either be increased or decreased based on the creditor's analysis of the individual tax return and any related tax schedules.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-E-2
paragraph.title: Guidelines for Analyzing IRS Form 1040.
paragraph.content: Guidelines for Analyzing IRS Form 1040. The table below contains guidelines for analyzing IRS Form 1040:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F
paragraph.content: Income Analysis: Corporate Tax Returns (IRS Form 1120).

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-1
paragraph.title: Description: Corporation.
paragraph.content: Description: Corporation. A corporation is a State-chartered business owned by its stockholders.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-2
paragraph.title: Need To Obtain Consumer Percentage of Ownership Information.
paragraph.content: Need To Obtain Consumer Percentage of Ownership Information.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-2-a
paragraph.content: Corporate compensation to the officers, generally in proportion to the percentage of ownership, is shown on the:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-2-a-i
paragraph.content: Corporate tax return IRS Form 1120; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-2-a-ii
paragraph.content: Individual tax returns.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-2-b
paragraph.content: When a consumer's percentage of ownership does not appear on the tax returns, the creditor must obtain the information from the corporation's accountant, along with evidence that the consumer has the right to any compensation.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-3
paragraph.title: Analyzing Corporate Tax Returns.
paragraph.content: Analyzing Corporate Tax Returns.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-3-a
paragraph.content: In order to determine a consumer's self-employed income from a corporation the adjusted business income must:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-3-a-i
paragraph.content: Be determined; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-3-a-ii
paragraph.content: Multiplied by the consumer's percentage of ownership in the business.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-3-b
paragraph.content: The table below describes the items found on IRS Form 1120 for which an adjustment must be made in order to determine adjusted business income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-G
paragraph.content: Income Analysis: “S” Corporation Tax Returns (IRS Form 1120S).

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-G-1
paragraph.title: Description: “S” Corporation.
paragraph.content: Description: “S” Corporation.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-G-1-a
paragraph.content: An “S” corporation is generally a small, start-up business, with gains and losses passed to stockholders in proportion to each stockholder's percentage of business ownership.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-G-1-b
paragraph.content: Income for owners of “S” corporations comes from IRS Form W-2 wages, and is taxed at the individual rate. The IRS Form 1120S, Compensation of Officers line item is transferred to the consumer's individual IRS Form 1040.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-G-2
paragraph.title: Analyzing “S” Corporation Tax Returns.
paragraph.content: Analyzing “S” Corporation Tax Returns.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-G-2-a
paragraph.content: “S” corporation depreciation and depletion may be added back to income in proportion to the consumer's share of the corporation's income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-G-2-b
paragraph.content: In addition, the income must also be reduced proportionately by the total obligations payable by the corporation in less than one year.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-G-2-c
paragraph.content: Important: The consumer's withdrawal of cash from the corporation may have a severe negative impact on the corporation's ability to continue operating, and must be considered in the income analysis.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H
paragraph.content: Income Analysis: Partnership Tax Returns (IRS Form 1065).

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-1
paragraph.title: Description: Partnership.
paragraph.content: Description: Partnership.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-1-a
paragraph.content: A partnership is formed when two or more individuals form a business, and share in profits, losses, and responsibility for running the company.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-1-b
paragraph.content: Each partner pays taxes on his/her proportionate share of the partnership's net income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-2
paragraph.title: Analyzing Partnership Tax Returns.
paragraph.content: Analyzing Partnership Tax Returns.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-2-a
paragraph.content: Both general and limited partnerships report income on IRS Form 1065, and the partners' share of income is carried over to Schedule E of IRS Form 1040.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-2-b
paragraph.content: The creditor must review IRS Form 1065 to assess the viability of the business. Both depreciation and depletion may be added back to the income in proportion to the consumer's share of income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-2-c
paragraph.content: Income must also be reduced proportionately by the total obligations payable by the partnership in less than one year.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-2-d
paragraph.content: Important: Cash withdrawals from the partnership may have a severe negative impact on the partnership's ability to continue operating, and must be considered in the income analysis.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A
paragraph.content: Alimony, Child Support, and Maintenance Income Criteria. Alimony, child support, or maintenance income may be considered effective, if:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-1
paragraph.content: Payments are likely to be received consistently for the first three years of the mortgage;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-2
paragraph.content: The consumer provides the required documentation, which includes a copy of the:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-2-i
paragraph.content: Final divorce decree;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-2-ii
paragraph.content: Legal separation agreement;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-2-iii
paragraph.content: Court order; or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-2-iv
paragraph.content: Voluntary payment agreement; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-3
paragraph.content: The consumer can provide acceptable evidence that payments have been received during the last 12 months, such as:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-3-i
paragraph.content: Cancelled checks;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-3-ii
paragraph.content: Deposit slips;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-3-iii
paragraph.content: Tax returns; or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-3-iv
paragraph.content: Court records.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-3-p13
paragraph.content: ```note Notes: i. Periods less than 12 months may be acceptable, provided the creditor can adequately document the payer's ability and willingness to make timely payments. ii. Child support may be “grossed up” under the same provisions as non-taxable income sources. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B
paragraph.content: Investment and Trust Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-1
paragraph.title: Analyzing Interest and Dividends.
paragraph.content: Analyzing Interest and Dividends.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-1-a
paragraph.content: Interest and dividend income may be used as long as tax returns or account statements support a two-year receipt history. This income must be averaged over the two years.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-1-b
paragraph.content: Subtract any funds that are derived from these sources, and are required for the cash investment, before calculating the projected interest or dividend income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-2
paragraph.title: Trust Income.
paragraph.content: Trust Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-2-a
paragraph.content: Income from trusts may be used if guaranteed, constant payments will continue for at least the first three years of the mortgage term.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-2-b
paragraph.content: Required trust income documentation includes a copy of the Trust Agreement or other trustee statement, confirming the:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-2-b-i
paragraph.content: Amount of the trust;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-2-b-ii
paragraph.content: Frequency of distribution; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-2-b-iii
paragraph.content: Duration of payments.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-2-c
paragraph.content: Trust account funds may be used for the required cash investment if the consumer provides adequate documentation that the withdrawal of funds will not negatively affect income. The consumer may use funds from the trust account for the required cash investment, but the trust income used to determine repayment ability cannot be affected negatively by its use.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-3
paragraph.title: Notes Receivable Income.
paragraph.content: Notes Receivable Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-3-a
paragraph.content: In order to include notes receivable income to qualify a consumer, he/she must provide:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-3-a-i
paragraph.content: A copy of the note to establish the amount and length of payment, and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-3-a-ii
paragraph.content: Evidence that these payments have been consistently received for the last 12 months through deposit slips, cancelled checks, or tax returns.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-3-b
paragraph.content: If the consumer is not the original payee on the note, the creditor must establish that the consumer is now a holder in due course, and able to enforce the note.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-4
paragraph.title: Eligible Investment Properties.
paragraph.content: Eligible Investment Properties.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-p14
paragraph.content: Follow the steps in the table below to calculate an investment property's income or loss if the property to be subject to a mortgage is an eligible investment property.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C
paragraph.content: Military, Government Agency, and Assistance Program Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1
paragraph.title: Military Income.
paragraph.content: Military Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a
paragraph.content: Military personnel not only receive base pay, butoftentimes are entitled to additional forms of pay, such as:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-i
paragraph.content: Income from variable housing allowances;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-ii
paragraph.content: Clothing allowances;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-iii
paragraph.content: Flight or hazard pay;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-iv
paragraph.content: Rations; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-v
paragraph.content: Proficiency pay.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-b
paragraph.content: These types of additional pay are acceptable when analyzing a consumer's income as long as the probability of such pay to continue is verified in writing.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-p16
paragraph.content: ```note Note:The tax-exempt nature of some of the above payments should also be considered. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-2
paragraph.title: VA Benefits.
paragraph.content: VA Benefits.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-2-a
paragraph.content: Direct compensation for service-related disabilities from the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) is acceptable, provided the creditor receives documentation from the VA.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-2-b
paragraph.content: Education benefits used to offset education expenses are not acceptable.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-3
paragraph.title: Government Assistance Programs.
paragraph.content: Government Assistance Programs.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-3-a
paragraph.content: Income received from government assistance programs is acceptable as long as the paying agency provides documentation indicating that the income is expected to continue for at least three years.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-3-b
paragraph.content: If the income from government assistance programs will not be received for at least three years, it may not be used in qualifying.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-3-c
paragraph.content: Unemployment income must be documented for two years, and there must be reasonable assurance that this income will continue. This requirement may apply to seasonal employment.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-4
paragraph.title: Mortgage Credit Certificates.
paragraph.content: Mortgage Credit Certificates.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-4-a
paragraph.content: If a government entity subsidizes the mortgage payments either through direct payments or tax rebates, these payments may be considered as acceptable income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-4-b
paragraph.content: Either type of subsidy may be added to gross income, or used directly to offset the mortgage payment, before calculating the qualifying ratios.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5
paragraph.title: Homeownership Subsidies.
paragraph.content: Homeownership Subsidies.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-a
paragraph.content: A monthly subsidy may be treated as income, if a consumer is receiving subsidies under the housing choice voucher home ownership option from a public housing agency (PHA). Although continuation of the homeownership voucher subsidy beyond the first year is subject to Congressional appropriation, for the purposes of underwriting, the subsidy will be assumed to continue for at least three years.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-b
paragraph.content: If the consumer is receiving the subsidy directly, the amount received is treated as income. The amount received may also be treated as nontaxable income and be “grossed up” by 25 percent, which means that the amount of the subsidy, plus 25 percent of that subsidy may be added to the consumer's income from employment and/or other sources.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-c
paragraph.content: Creditors may treat this subsidy as an “offset” to the monthly mortgage payment (that is, reduce the monthly mortgage payment by the amount of the home ownership assistance payment before dividing by the monthly income to determine the payment-to-income and debt-to-income ratios). The subsidy payment must not pass through the consumer's hands.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-d
paragraph.content: The assistance payment must be:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-d-i
paragraph.content: Paid directly to the servicing creditor; or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-d-ii
paragraph.content: Placed in an account that only the servicing creditor may access.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-d-p17
paragraph.content: ```note Note:Assistance payments made directly to the consumer must be treated as income. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D
paragraph.content: Rental Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-1
paragraph.title: Analyzing the Stability of Rental Income.
paragraph.content: Analyzing the Stability of Rental Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-1-a
paragraph.content: Rent received for properties owned by the consumer is acceptable as long as the creditor can document the stability of the rental income through:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-1-a-i
paragraph.content: A current lease;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-1-a-ii
paragraph.content: An agreement to lease, or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-1-a-iii
paragraph.content: A rental history over the previous 24 months that is free of unexplained gaps greater than three months (such gaps could be explained by student, seasonal, or military renters, or property rehabilitation).

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-1-b
paragraph.content: A separate schedule of real estate is not required for rental properties as long as all properties are documented on the Uniform Residential Loan Application.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-1-p18
paragraph.content: ```note Note:The underwriting analysis may not consider rental income from any property being vacated by the consumer, except under the circumstances described below. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-2
paragraph.title: Rental Income From Consumer Occupied Property.
paragraph.content: Rental Income From Consumer Occupied Property.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-2-a
paragraph.content: The rent for multiple unit property where the consumer resides in one or more units and charges rent to tenants of other units may be used for qualifying purposes.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-2-b
paragraph.content: Projected rent for the tenant-occupied units only may:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-2-b-i
paragraph.content: Be considered gross income, only after deducting vacancy and maintenance factors, and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-2-b-ii
paragraph.content: Not be used as a direct offset to the mortgage payment.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-3
paragraph.title: Income from Roommates in a Single Family Property.
paragraph.content: Income from Roommates in a Single Family Property.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-3-a
paragraph.content: Income from roommates in a single family property occupied as the consumer's primary residence is not acceptable. Rental income from boarders however, is acceptable, if the boarders are related by blood, marriage, or law.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-3-b
paragraph.content: The rental income may be considered effective, if shown on the consumer's tax return. If not on the tax return, rental income paid by the boarder may not be used in qualifying.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-4
paragraph.title: Documentation Required To Verify Rental Income.
paragraph.content: Documentation Required To Verify Rental Income. Analysis of the following required documentation is necessary to verify all consumer rental income:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-4-a
paragraph.content: IRS Form 1040 Schedule E; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-4-b
paragraph.content: Current leases/rental agreements.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-5
paragraph.title: Analyzing IRS Form 1040 Schedule E.
paragraph.content: Analyzing IRS Form 1040 Schedule E.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-5-a
paragraph.content: The IRS Form 1040 Schedule E is required to verify all rental income. Depreciation shown on Schedule E may be added back to the net income or loss.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-5-b
paragraph.content: Positive rental income is considered gross income for qualifying purposes, while negative income must be treated as a recurring liability.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-5-c
paragraph.content: The creditor must confirm that the consumer still owns each property listed, by comparing Schedule E with the real estate owned section of the URLA.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-6
paragraph.title: Using Current Leases To Analyze Rental Income.
paragraph.content: Using Current Leases To Analyze Rental Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-6-a
paragraph.content: The consumer can provide a current signed lease or other rental agreement for a property that was acquired since the last income tax filing, and is not shown on Schedule E.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-6-b
paragraph.content: In order to calculate the rental income:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-6-b-i
paragraph.content: Reduce the gross rental amount by 25 percent for vacancies and maintenance;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-6-b-ii
paragraph.content: Subtract PITI and any homeowners association dues; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-6-b-iii
paragraph.content: Apply the resulting amount to income, if positive, or recurring debts, if negative.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-7
paragraph.title: Exclusion of Rental Income From Property Being Vacated by the Consumer.
paragraph.content: Exclusion of Rental Income From Property Being Vacated by the Consumer. Underwriters may not consider any rental income from a consumer's principal residence that is being vacated in favor of another principal residence, except under the conditions described below:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-8
paragraph.title: Policy Exceptions Regarding the Exclusion of Rental Income From a Principal Residence Being Vacated by a Consumer.
paragraph.content: Policy Exceptions Regarding the Exclusion of Rental Income From a Principal Residence Being Vacated by a Consumer.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-p19
paragraph.content: ```note Notes: i. This policy assures that a consumer either has sufficient income to make both mortgage payments without any rentalincome, or has an equity position not likely to result in defaulting on the mortgage on the property being vacated. ii. This applies solely to a principal residence being vacated in favor of another principal residence. It does not apply to existing rental properties disclosed on the loan application and confirmed by tax returns (Schedule E of form IRS 1040). ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-p20
paragraph.content: When a consumer vacates a principal residence in favor of another principal residence, the rental income, reduced by the appropriate vacancy factor, may be considered in the underwriting analysis under the circumstances listed in the table below.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E
paragraph.content: Non Taxable and Projected Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-1
paragraph.title: Types of Non Taxable Income.
paragraph.content: Types of Non Taxable Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-2
paragraph.title: Adding Non Taxable Income to a Consumer's Gross Income.
paragraph.content: Adding Non Taxable Income to a Consumer's Gross Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-2-a
paragraph.content: The amount of continuing tax savings attributed to regular income not subject to Federal taxes may be added to the consumer's gross income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-2-b
paragraph.content: The percentage of non-taxable income that may be added cannot exceed the appropriate tax rate for the income amount. Additional allowances for dependents are not acceptable.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-2-c
paragraph.content: The creditor:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-2-c-i
paragraph.content: Must document and support the amount of income grossed up for any non-taxable income source, and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-2-c-ii
paragraph.content: Should use the tax rate used to calculate the consumer's last year's income tax.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-2-c-p23
paragraph.content: ```note Note: If the consumer is not required to file a Federal tax return, the tax rate to use is 25 percent. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3
paragraph.title: Analyzing Projected Income.
paragraph.content: Analyzing Projected Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-a
paragraph.content: Projected or hypothetical income is not acceptable for qualifying purposes. However, exceptions are permitted for income from the following sources:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-a-i
paragraph.content: Cost-of-living adjustments;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-a-ii
paragraph.content: Performance raises; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-a-iii
paragraph.content: Bonuses.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-b
paragraph.content: For the above exceptions to apply, the income must be:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-b-i
paragraph.content: Verified in writing by the employer; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-b-ii
paragraph.content: Scheduled to begin within 60 days of loan closing.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-4
paragraph.title: Project Income for New Job.
paragraph.content: Project Income for New Job.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-4-a
paragraph.content: Projected income is acceptable for qualifying purposes for a consumer scheduled to start a new job within 60 days of loan closing if there is a guaranteed, non-revocable contract for employment.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-4-b
paragraph.content: The creditor must verify that the consumer will have sufficient income or cash reserves to support the mortgage payment and any other obligations between loan closing and the start of employment. Examples of this type of scenario are teachers whose contracts begin with the new school year, or physicians beginning a residency after the loan closes fall under this category.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-4-c
paragraph.content: The loan is not eligible for endorsement if the loan closes more than 60 days before the consumer starts the new job. To be eligible for endorsement, the creditor must obtain from the consumer a pay stub or other acceptable evidence indicating that he/she has started the new job.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-p22
paragraph.content: Certain types of regular income may not be subject to Federal tax. Such types of nontaxable income include:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-p22-a
paragraph.content: Some portion of Social Security, some Federal government employee retirement income, Railroad Retirement Benefits, and some State government retirement income:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-p22-b
paragraph.content: Certain types of disability and public assistance payments;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-p22-c
paragraph.content: Child support;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-p22-d
paragraph.content: Military allowances; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-p22-e
paragraph.content: Other income that is documented as being exempt from Federal income taxes.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-1
paragraph.title: Types of Recurring Obligation.
paragraph.content: Types of Recurring Obligation. Recurring obligations include:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-1-a
paragraph.content: All installment loans;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-1-b
paragraph.content: Revolving charge accounts;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-1-c
paragraph.content: Real estate loans;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-1-d
paragraph.content: Alimony;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-1-e
paragraph.content: Child support; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-1-f
paragraph.content: Other continuing obligations.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-2
paragraph.title: Debt to Income Ratio Computation for Recurring Obligations.
paragraph.content: Debt to Income Ratio Computation for Recurring Obligations.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-2-a
paragraph.content: The creditor must include the following when computing the debt to income ratios for recurring obligations:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-2-a-i
paragraph.content: Monthly housing expense; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-2-a-ii
paragraph.content: Additional recurring charges extending ten months or more, such as

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-2-a-ii-a
paragraph.content: Payments on installment accounts;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-2-a-ii-b
paragraph.content: Child support or separate maintenance payments;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-2-a-ii-c
paragraph.content: Revolving accounts; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-2-a-ii-d
paragraph.content: Alimony.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-2-b
paragraph.content: Debts lasting less than ten months must be included if the amount of the debt affects the consumer's ability to pay the mortgage during the months immediately after loan closing, especially if the consumer will have limited or no cash assets after loan closing.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-2-p24
paragraph.content: ```note Note:Monthly payments on revolving or open-ended accounts, regardless of the balance, are counted as a liability for qualifying purposes even if the account appears likely to be paid off within 10 months or less. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-3
paragraph.title: Revolving Account Monthly Payment Calculation.
paragraph.content: Revolving Account Monthly Payment Calculation. If the credit report shows any revolving accounts with an outstanding balance but no specific minimum monthly payment, the payment must be calculated as the greater of:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-3-a
paragraph.content: 5 percent of the balance; or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-3-p25
paragraph.content: ```note Note: If the actual monthly payment is documented from the creditor or the creditor obtains a copy of the current statement reflecting the monthly payment, that amount may be used for qualifying purposes. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-4
paragraph.title: Reduction of Alimony Payment for Qualifying Ratio Calculation.
paragraph.content: Reduction of Alimony Payment for Qualifying Ratio Calculation. Since there are tax consequences of alimony payments, the creditor may choose to treat the monthly alimony obligation as a reduction from the consumer's gross income when calculating qualifying ratios, rather than treating it as a monthly obligation.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-1
paragraph.title: Definition: Contingent Liability.
paragraph.content: Definition: Contingent Liability. A contingent liability exists when an individual is held responsible for payment of a debt if another party, jointly or severally obligated, defaults on the payment.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-2
paragraph.title: Application of Contingent Liability Policies.
paragraph.content: Application of Contingent Liability Policies. The contingent liability policies described in this topic apply unless the consumer can provide conclusive evidence from the debt holder that there is no possibility that the debt holder will pursue debt collection against him/her should the other party default.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-3
paragraph.title: Contingent Liability on Mortgage Assumptions.
paragraph.content: Contingent Liability on Mortgage Assumptions. Contingent liability must be considered when the consumer remains obligated on an outstanding FHA-insured, VA-guaranteed, or conventional mortgage secured by property that:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-3-a
paragraph.content: Has been sold or traded within the last 12 months without a release of liability, or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-3-b
paragraph.content: Is to be sold on assumption without a release of liability being obtained.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-4
paragraph.title: Exemption From Contingent Liability Policy on Mortgage Assumptions.
paragraph.content: Exemption From Contingent Liability Policy on Mortgage Assumptions. When a mortgage is assumed, contingent liabilities need not be considered if the:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-4-a
paragraph.content: Originating creditor of the mortgage being underwritten obtains, from the servicer of the assumed loan, a payment history showing that the mortgage has been current during the previous 12 months, or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-4-b
paragraph.content: Value of the property, as established by an appraisal or the sales price on the HUD-1 Settlement Statement from the sale of the property, results in a loan-to-value (LTV) ratio of 75 percent or less.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-5
paragraph.title: Contingent Liability on Cosigned Obligations.
paragraph.content: Contingent Liability on Cosigned Obligations.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-5-a
paragraph.content: Contingent liability applies, and the debt must be included in the underwriting analysis, if an individual applying for a mortgage is a cosigner/co-obligor on:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-5-a-i
paragraph.content: A car loan;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-5-a-ii
paragraph.content: A student loan;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-5-a-iii
paragraph.content: A mortgage; or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-5-a-iv
paragraph.content: Any other obligation.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-5-b
paragraph.content: If the creditor obtains documented proof that the primary obligor has been making regular payments during the previous 12 months, and does not have a history of delinquent payments on the loan during that time, the payment does not have to be included in the consumer's monthly obligations.

appendixSection.label: 1026-Q-h5
appendixSection.subject: V. Consumer Liabilities: Projected Obligations and Obligations Not Considered Debt

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h5-1
paragraph.title: Projected Obligations.
paragraph.content: Projected Obligations.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h5-1-a
paragraph.content: Debt payments, such as a student loan or balloon-payment note scheduled to begin or come due within 12 months of the mortgage loan closing, must be included by the creditor as anticipated monthly obligations during the underwriting analysis.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h5-1-b
paragraph.content: Debt payments do not have to be classified as projected obligations if the consumer provides written evidence that the debt will be deferred to a period outside the 12-month timeframe.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h5-1-c
paragraph.content: Balloon-payment notes that come due within one year of loan closing must be considered in the underwriting analysis.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h5-2
paragraph.title: Obligations Not Considered Debt.
paragraph.content: Obligations Not Considered Debt. Obligations not considered debt, and therefore not subtracted from gross income, include:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h5-2-a
paragraph.content: Federal, State, and local taxes;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h5-2-b
paragraph.content: Federal Insurance Contributions Act (FICA) or other retirement contributions, such as 401(k) accounts (including repayment of debt secured by these funds):

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h5-2-c
paragraph.content: Commuting costs;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h5-2-d
paragraph.content: Union dues;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h5-2-e
paragraph.content: Open accounts with zero balances;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h5-2-f
paragraph.content: Automatic deductions to savings accounts;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h5-2-g
paragraph.content: Child care; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h5-2-h
paragraph.content: Voluntary deductions.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-p1-p1
paragraph.content: Section 1026.43(e)(2)(vi) provides that, to satisfy the requirements for a qualified mortgage under § 1026.43(e)(2), the ratio of the consumer's total monthly debt to total monthly income at the time of consummation cannot exceed 43 percent. Section 1026.43(e)(2)(vi)(A) requires the creditor to calculate the ratio of the consumer's total monthly debt to total monthly income using the following standards, with additional requirements for calculating debt and income appearing in § 1026.43(e)(2)(vi)(B).

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-5
paragraph.title: Qualified mortgage defined—small creditor portfolio loans.
paragraph.content: Qualified mortgage defined—small creditor portfolio loans.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-5-i
paragraph.content: Notwithstanding paragraph (e)(2) of this section, a qualified mortgage is a covered transaction:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-5-i-A
paragraph.content: That satisfies the requirements of paragraph (e)(2) of this section other than the requirements of paragraph (e)(2)(vi) and without regard to the standards in appendix Q to this part;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-5-i-B
paragraph.content: For which the creditor considers at or before consummation the consumer's monthly debt-to-income ratio or residual income and verifies the debt obligations and income used to determine that ratio in accordance with paragraph (c)(7) of this section, except that the calculation of the payment on the covered transaction for purposes of determining the consumer's total monthly debt obligations in paragraph (c)(7)(i)(A) shall be determined in accordance with paragraph (e)(2)(iv) of this section instead of paragraph (c)(5) of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-5-i-C
paragraph.content: That is not subject, at consummation, to a commitment to be acquired by another person, other than a person that satisfies the requirements of paragraph (e)(5)(i)(D) of this section; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-5-i-D
paragraph.content: For which the creditor satisfies the requirements stated in § 1026.35(b)(2)(iii)(B) and (C).

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-5-ii
paragraph.content: A qualified mortgage extended pursuant to paragraph (e)(5)(i) of this section immediately loses its status as a qualified mortgage under paragraph (e)(5)(i) if legal title to the qualified mortgage is sold, assigned, or otherwise transferred to another person except when:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-5-ii-A
paragraph.content: The qualified mortgage is sold, assigned, or otherwise transferred to another person three years or more after consummation of the qualified mortgage;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-5-ii-B
paragraph.content: The qualified mortgage is sold, assigned, or otherwise transferred to a creditor that satisfies the requirements of paragraph (e)(5)(i)(D) of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-5-ii-C
paragraph.content: The qualified mortgage is sold, assigned, or otherwise transferred to another person pursuant to a capital restoration plan or other action under 12 U.S.C. 1831o, actions or instructions of any person acting as conservator, receiver, or bankruptcy trustee, an order of a State or Federal government agency with jurisdiction to examine the creditor pursuant to State or Federal law, or an agreement between the creditor and such an agency; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-5-ii-D
paragraph.content: The qualified mortgage is sold, assigned, or otherwise transferred pursuant to a merger of the creditor with another person or acquisition of the creditor by another person or of another person by the creditor.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4
paragraph.title: Qualified mortgage defined—special rules
paragraph.content: Qualified mortgage defined—special rules —

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-i
paragraph.title: General.
paragraph.content: General. Notwithstanding paragraph (e)(2) of this section, a qualified mortgage is a covered transaction that satisfies:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-i-A
paragraph.content: The requirements of paragraphs (e)(2)(i) through (iii) of this section; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-i-B
paragraph.content: One or more of the criteria in paragraph (e)(4)(ii) of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii
paragraph.title: Eligible loans.
paragraph.content: Eligible loans. A qualified mortgage under this paragraph (e)(4) must be one of the following at consummation:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii-A
paragraph.content: A loan that is eligible:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii-A-1
paragraph.content: To be purchased or guaranteed by the Federal National Mortgage Association or the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation operating under the conservatorship or receivership of the Federal Housing Finance Agency pursuant to section 1367(a) of the Federal Housing Enterprises Financial Safety and Soundness Act of 1992 (12 U.S.C. 4617(a)); or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii-A-2
paragraph.content: To be purchased or guaranteed by any limited-life regulatory entity succeeding the charter of either the Federal National Mortgage Association or the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation pursuant to section 1367(i) of the Federal Housing Enterprises Financial Safety and Soundness Act of 1992 (12 U.S.C. 4617(i));

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii-B
paragraph.content: A loan that is eligible to be insured by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development under the National Housing Act (12 U.S.C. 1707 et seq.);

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii-C
paragraph.content: A loan that is eligible to be guaranteed the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii-D
paragraph.content: A loan that is eligible to be guaranteed by the U.S. Department of Agriculture pursuant to 42 U.S.C. 1472(h); or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii-E
paragraph.content: A loan that is eligible to be insured by the Rural Housing Service.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-iii
paragraph.title: Sunset of special rules.
paragraph.content: Sunset of special rules.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-iii-A
paragraph.content: Each respective special rule described in paragraph (e)(4)(ii)(B), (C), (D), or (E) of this section shall expire on the effective date of a rule issued by each respective agency pursuant to its authority under TILA section 129C(b)(3)(ii) to define a qualified mortgage.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-iii-B
paragraph.content: Unless otherwise expired under paragraph (e)(4)(iii)(A) of this section, the special rules in this paragraph (e)(4) are available only for covered transactions consummated on or before January 10, 2021.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-A
paragraph.content: A loan with a balloon payment, as defined in § 1026.18(s)(5)(i), using:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-A-1
paragraph.content: The maximum payment scheduled during the first five years after the date on which the first regular periodic payment will be due for a loan that is not a higher-priced covered transaction; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-A-2
paragraph.content: The maximum payment in the payment schedule, including any balloon payment, for a higher-priced covered transaction;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-1
paragraph.title: Safe harbor and presumption of compliance—
paragraph.content: Safe harbor and presumption of compliance.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-1-i
paragraph.title: Safe harbor for transactions that are not higher-priced covered transactions.
paragraph.content: Safe harbor for loans that are not higher-priced covered transactions. A creditor or assignee of a qualified mortgage, as defined in paragraphs (e)(2), (e)(4), (e)(5), (e)(6), or (f) of this section, that is not a higher-priced covered transaction, as defined in paragraph (b)(4) of this section, complies with the repayment ability requirements of paragraph (c) of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-1-ii
paragraph.title: Presumption of compliance for higher-priced covered transactions.
paragraph.content: Presumption of compliance for higher-priced covered transactions.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-1-ii-A
paragraph.content: A creditor or assignee of a qualified mortgage, as defined in paragraph (e)(2), (e)(4), (e)(5), (e)(6), or (f) of this section, that is a higher-priced covered transaction, as defined in paragraph (b)(4) of this section, is presumed to comply with the repayment ability requirements of paragraph (c) of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-1-ii-B
paragraph.content: To rebut the presumption of compliance described in paragraph (e)(1)(ii)(A) of this section, it must be proven that, despite meeting the prerequisites of paragraph (e)(2), (e)(4), (e)(5), (e)(6), or (f) of this section, the creditor did not make a reasonable and good faith determination of the consumer's repayment ability at the time of consummation, by showing that the consumer's income, debt obligations, alimony, child support, and the consumer's monthly payment (including mortgage-related obligations) on the covered transaction and on any simultaneous loans of which the creditor was aware at consummation would leave the consumer with insufficient residual income or assets other than the value of the dwelling (including any real property attached to the dwelling) that secures the loan with which to meet living expenses, including any recurring and material non-debt obligations of which the creditor was aware at the time of consummation.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4
paragraph.title: Repayment ability.
paragraph.content: Repayment ability. Extend credit subject to § 1026.32 to a consumer based on the value of the consumer's collateral without regard to the consumer's repayment ability as of consummation, including the consumer's current and reasonably expected income, employment, assets other than the collateral, current obligations, and mortgage-related obligations.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-i
paragraph.title: Mortgage-related obligations.
paragraph.content: Mortgage-related obligations. For purposes of this paragraph (a)(4), mortgage-related obligations are expected property taxes, premiums for mortgage-related insurance required by the creditor as set forth in § 1026.35(b), and similar expenses.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-ii
paragraph.title: Verification of repayment ability.
paragraph.content: Verification of repayment ability. Under this paragraph (a)(4) a creditor must verify the consumer's repayment ability as follows:

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-ii-A
paragraph.content: A creditor must verify amounts of income or assets that it relies on to determine repayment ability, including expected income or assets, by the consumer's Internal Revenue Service Form W-2, tax returns, payroll receipts, financial institution records, or other third-party documents that provide reasonably reliable evidence of the consumer's income or assets.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-ii-B
paragraph.content: Notwithstanding paragraph (a)(4)(ii)(A), a creditor has not violated paragraph (a)(4)(ii) if the amounts of income and assets that the creditor relied upon in determining repayment ability are not materially greater than the amounts of the consumer's income or assets that the creditor could have verified pursuant to paragraph (a)(4)(ii)(A) at the time the loan was consummated.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-ii-C
paragraph.content: A creditor must verify the consumer's current obligations.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-iii
paragraph.title: Presumption of compliance.
paragraph.content: Presumption of compliance. A creditor is presumed to have complied with this paragraph (a)(4) with respect to a transaction if the creditor:

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-iii-A
paragraph.content: Verifies the consumer's repayment ability as provided in paragraph (a)(4)(ii);

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-iii-B
paragraph.content: Determines the consumer's repayment ability using the largest payment of principal and interest scheduled in the first seven years following consummation and taking into account current obligations and mortgage-related obligations as defined in paragraph (a)(4)(i); and

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-iii-C
paragraph.content: Assesses the consumer's repayment ability taking into account at least one of the following: The ratio of total debt obligations to income, or the income the consumer will have after paying debt obligations.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-iv
paragraph.title: Exclusions from presumption of compliance.
paragraph.content: Exclusions from presumption of compliance. Notwithstanding the previous paragraph, no presumption of compliance is available for a transaction for which:

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-iv-A
paragraph.content: The regular periodic payments for the first seven years would cause the principal balance to increase; or

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-iv-B
paragraph.content: The term of the loan is less than seven years and the regular periodic payments when aggregated do not fully amortize the outstanding principal balance.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-v
paragraph.title: Exemption.
paragraph.content: Exemption. This paragraph (a)(4) does not apply to temporary or “bridge” loans with terms of twelve months or less, such as a loan to purchase a new dwelling where the consumer plans to sell a current dwelling within twelve months.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2
paragraph.title: Qualified mortgage defined—general.
paragraph.content: Qualified mortgage defined—general. Except as provided in paragraph (e)(4), (e)(5), (e)(6), or (f) of this section, a qualified mortgage is a covered transaction:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-i
paragraph.content: That provides for regular periodic payments that are substantially equal, except for the effect that any interest rate change after consummation has on the payment in the case of an adjustable-rate or step-rate mortgage, that do not:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-i-A
paragraph.content: Result in an increase of the principal balance;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-i-B
paragraph.content: Allow the consumer to defer repayment of principal, except as provided in paragraph (f) of this section; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-i-C
paragraph.content: Result in a balloon payment, as defined in § 1026.18(s)(5)(i), except as provided in paragraph (f) of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-ii
paragraph.content: For which the loan term does not exceed 30 years;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iii
paragraph.content: For which the total points and fees payable in connection with the loan do not exceed the amounts specified in paragraph (e)(3) of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv
paragraph.content: For which the creditor underwrites the loan, taking into account the monthly payment for mortgage-related obligations, using:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv-A
paragraph.content: The maximum interest rate that may apply during the first five years after the date on which the first regular periodic payment will be due; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv-B
paragraph.content: Periodic payments of principal and interest that will repay either:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv-B-1
paragraph.content: The outstanding principal balance over the remaining term of the loan as of the date the interest rate adjusts to the maximum interest rate set forth in paragraph (e)(2)(iv)(A) of this section, assuming the consumer will have made all required payments as due prior to that date; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv-B-2
paragraph.content: The loan amount over the loan term;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-v
paragraph.content: For which the creditor considers and verifies at or before consummation the following:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-v-A
paragraph.content: The consumer's current or reasonably expected income or assets other than the value of the dwelling (including any real property attached to the dwelling) that secures the loan, in accordance with appendix Q and paragraphs (c)(2)(i) and (c)(4) of this section; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-v-B
paragraph.content: The consumer's current debt obligations, alimony, and child support in accordance with appendix Q and paragraphs (c)(2)(vi) and (c)(3) of this section; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-vi
paragraph.content: For which the ratio of the consumer's total monthly debt to total monthly income at the time of consummation does not exceed 43 percent. For purposes of this paragraph (e)(2)(vi), the ratio of the consumer's total monthly debt to total monthly income is determined:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-vi-A
paragraph.content: Except as provided in paragraph (e)(2)(vi)(B) of this section, in accordance with the standards in appendix Q;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-vi-B
paragraph.content: Using the consumer's monthly payment on:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-vi-B-1
paragraph.content: The covered transaction, including the monthly payment for mortgage-related obligations, in accordance with paragraph (e)(2)(iv) of this section; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-vi-B-2
paragraph.content: Any simultaneous loan that the creditor knows or has reason to know will be made, in accordance with paragraphs (c)(2)(iv) and (c)(6) of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-2
paragraph.title: Post-consummation transfer of balloon-payment qualified mortgage.
paragraph.content: Post-consummation transfer of balloon-payment qualified mortgage. A balloon-payment qualified mortgage, extended pursuant to paragraph (f)(1), immediately loses its status as a qualified mortgage under paragraph (f)(1) if legal title to the balloon-payment qualified mortgage is sold, assigned, or otherwise transferred to another person except when:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-2-i
paragraph.content: The balloon-payment qualified mortgage is sold, assigned, or otherwise transferred to another person three years or more after consummation of the balloon-payment qualified mortgage;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-2-ii
paragraph.content: The balloon-payment qualified mortgage is sold, assigned, or otherwise transferred to a creditor that satisfies the requirements of paragraph (f)(1)(vi) of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-2-iii
paragraph.content: The balloon-payment qualified mortgage is sold, assigned, or otherwise transferred to another person pursuant to a capital restoration plan or other action under 12 U.S.C. 1831o, actions or instructions of any person acting as conservator, receiver or bankruptcy trustee, an order of a State or Federal governmental agency with jurisdiction to examine the creditor pursuant to State or Federal law, or an agreement between the creditor and such an agency; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-2-iv
paragraph.content: The balloon-payment qualified mortgage is sold, assigned, or otherwise transferred pursuant to a merger of the creditor with another person or acquisition of the creditor by another person or of another person by the creditor.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-a-3-vi
paragraph.content: An extension of credit made pursuant to a program authorized by sections 101 and 109 of the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 (12 U.S.C. 5211; 5219);

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-6
paragraph.title: Applicability.
paragraph.content: Applicability. This paragraph (g) applies only if a covered transaction is consummated with a prepayment penalty and is not violated if:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-6-i
paragraph.content: A covered transaction is consummated without a prepayment penalty; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-6-ii
paragraph.content: The creditor and consumer do not consummate a covered transaction.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-1
paragraph.title: Repayment ability.
paragraph.content: Requirement to escrow for property taxes and insurance. Except as provided in paragraph (b)(2) of this section, a creditor may not extend a higher-priced mortgage loan secured by a first lien on a consuconsumer's principal dwelling unless an escrow account is established before consummation for payment of property taxes and premiums for mortgage-related insurance required by the creditor, such as insurance against loss of or damage to property, or against liability arising out of the ownership or use of the property, or insurance protecting the creditor against the consumer's default or other credit loss. For purposes of this paragraph (b), the term “escrow account” has the same meaning as under Regulation X (12 CFR 1024.17(b)), as amended.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-3
paragraph.title: Escrows
paragraph.content: Cancellation—

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-3-i
paragraph.title: Failure to escrow for property taxes and insurance.
paragraph.content: General. Except as provided in paragraph (b)(3)(ii) of this section, a creditor or servicer may cancel an escrow account required in paragraph (b)(1) of this section only upon the earlier of:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-3-i-A
paragraph.content: Termination of the underlying debt obligation; or

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-3-i-B
paragraph.content: Receipt no earlier than five years after consummation of a consumer's request to cancel the escrow account.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-3-ii
paragraph.title: Exemptions for loans secured by shares in a cooperative and for certain condominium units.
paragraph.content: Delayed cancellation. Notwithstanding paragraph (b)(3)(i) of this section, a creditor or servicer shall not cancel an escrow account pursuant to a consumer's request described in paragraph (b)(3)(i)(B) of this section unless the following conditions are satisfied:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-3-ii-A
paragraph.content: The unpaid principal balance is less than 80 percent of the original value of the property securing the underlying debt obligation; and

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-3-ii-B
paragraph.content: The consumer currently is not delinquent or in default on the underlying debt obligation.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2
paragraph.title: Prepayment penalties.
paragraph.content: Exemptions. Notwithstanding paragraph (b)(1) of this section:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-i
paragraph.content: An escrow account need not be established for:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-i-A
paragraph.content: A transaction secured by shares in a cooperative;

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-i-B
paragraph.content: A transaction to finance the initial construction of a dwelling;

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-i-C
paragraph.content: A temporary or “bridge” loan with a loan term of twelve months or less, such as a loan to purchase a new dwelling where the consumer plans to sell a current dwelling within twelve months; or

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-i-D
paragraph.content: A reverse mortgage transaction subject to § 1026.33(c).

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-ii
paragraph.content: Insurance premiums described in paragraph (b)(1) of this section need not be included in escrow accounts for loans secured by dwellings in condominiums, planned unit developments, or other common interest communities in which dwelling ownership requires participation in a governing association, where the governing association has an obligation to the dwelling owners to maintain a master policy insuring all dwellings.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii
paragraph.content: Except as provided in paragraph (b)(2)(v) of this section, an escrow account need not be established for a transaction if, at the time of consummation:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-A
paragraph.content: During the preceding calendar year, the creditor extended more than 50 percent of its total covered transactions, as defined by § 1026.43(b)(1), secured by a first lien, on properties that are located in counties that are either “rural” or “underserved,” as set forth in paragraph (b)(2)(iv) of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-B
paragraph.content: During the preceding calendar year, the creditor and its affiliates together originated 500 or fewer covered transactions, as defined by § 1026.43(b)(1), secured by a first lien; and

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-C
paragraph.content: As of the end of the preceding calendar year, the creditor had total assets of less than $2,000,000,000; this asset threshold shall adjust automatically each year, based on the year-to-year change in the average of the Consumer Price Index for Urban Wage Earners and Clerical Workers, not seasonally adjusted, for each 12-month period ending in November, with rounding to the nearest million dollars (see comment 35(b)(2)(iii)-1.iii for the current threshold); and

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-D
paragraph.content: Neither the creditor nor its affiliate maintains an escrow account of the type described in paragraph (b)(1) of this section for any extension of consumer credit secured by real property or a dwelling that the creditor or its affiliate currently services, other than:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-D-1
paragraph.content: Escrow accounts established for first-lien higher-priced mortgage loans on or after April 1, 2010, and before June 1, 2013; or

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-D-2
paragraph.content: Escrow accounts established after consummation as an accommodation to distressed consumers to assist such consumers in avoiding default or foreclosure.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iv
paragraph.content: For purposes of paragraph (b)(2)(iii)(A) of this section:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iv-A
paragraph.content: A county is “rural” during a calendar year if it is neither in a metropolitan statistical area nor in a micropolitan statistical area that is adjacent to a metropolitan statistical area, as those terms are defined by the U.S. Office of Management and Budget and as they are applied under currently applicable Urban Influence Codes (UICs), established by the United States Department of Agriculture's Economic Research Service (USDA-ERS). A creditor may rely as a safe harbor on the list of counties published by the Bureau to determine whether a county qualifies as “rural” for a particular calendar year.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iv-B
paragraph.content: A county is “underserved” during a calendar year if, according to Home Mortgage Disclosure Act (HMDA) data for the preceding calendar year, no more than two creditors extended covered transactions, as defined in § 1026.43(b)(1), secured by a first lien, five or more times in the county. A creditor may rely as a safe harbor on the list of counties published by the Bureau to determine whether a county qualifies as “underserved” for a particular calendar year.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-v
paragraph.content: Notwithstanding paragraph (b)(2)(iii) of this section, an escrow account must be established pursuant to paragraph (b)(1) of this section for any first-lien higher-priced mortgage loan that, at consummation, is subject to a commitment to be acquired by a person that does not satisfy the conditions in paragraph (b)(2)(iii) of this section, unless otherwise exempted by this paragraph (b)(2).

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-6
paragraph.title: Qualified mortgage defined—temporary balloon-payment qualified mortgage rules.
paragraph.content: Qualified mortgage defined—temporary balloon-payment qualified mortgage rules.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-6-i
paragraph.content: Notwithstanding paragraph (e)(2) of this section, a qualified mortgage is a covered transaction:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-6-i-A
paragraph.content: That satisfies the requirements of paragraph (f) of this section other than the requirements of paragraph (f)(1)(vi); and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-6-i-B
paragraph.content: For which the creditor satisfies the requirements stated in § 1026.35(b)(2)(iii)(B) and (C).

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-6-ii
paragraph.content: The provisions of this paragraph (e)(6) apply only to covered transactions consummated on or before January 10, 2016.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-a-2
paragraph.content: “Average prime offer rate” means an annual percentage rate that is derived from average interest rates, points, and other loan pricing terms currently offered to consumers by a representative sample of creditors for mortgage transactions that have low-risk pricing characteristics. The Bureau publishes average prime offer rates for a broad range of types of transactions in a table updated at least weekly as well as the methodology the Bureau uses to derive these rates.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-ii
paragraph.content: The dollar amounts, including the loan amounts, in paragraph (e)(3)(i) of this section shall be adjusted annually on January 1 by the annual percentage change in the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers (CPI-U) that was reported on the preceding June 1. See the official commentary to this paragraph (e)(3)(ii) for the current dollar amounts.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-a-1
paragraph.content: “Higher-priced mortgage loan” means a closed-end consumer creditit transaction secured by the consumer's principal dwelling with an annual percentage rate that exceeds the average prime offer rate for a comparable transaction as of the date the interest rate is set:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-a-1-i
paragraph.content: By 1.5 or more percentage points for loans secured by a first lien with a principal obligation at consummation that does not exceed the limit in effect as of the date the transaction's interest rate is set for the maximum principal obligation eligible for purchase by Freddie Mac;

paragraph.label: 1026-35-a-1-ii
paragraph.content: By 2.5 or more percentage points for loans secured by a first lien with a principal obligation at consummation that exceeds the limit in effect as of the date the transaction's interest rate is set for the maximum principal obligation eligible for purchase by Freddie Mac; or

paragraph.label: 1026-35-a-1-iii
paragraph.content: By 3.5 or more percentage points for loans secured by a subordinate lien.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv-B
paragraph.content: Periodic payments of principal and interest that will repay either:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv-B-1
paragraph.content: The outstanding principal balance over the remaining term of the loan as of the date the interest rate adjusts to the maximum interest rate set forth in paragraph (e)(2)(iv)(A) of this section, assuming the consumer will have made all required payments as due prior to that date; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv-B-2
paragraph.content: The loan amount over the loan term;
